we must choose now—be cursed or be blessed.

So do not seek a savior soft and mild,
who leaves your sinful nature reconciled.
Instead embrace the warrior divine
whose blade transforms your water into wine,
whose righteous anger sets the world aflame,
whose love and justice are one and the same.

The Cleaving

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
Not the meek lamb we portray
in stained glass windows day by day,
but lion fierce with blazing eyes,
who tears apart our sweet disguise.

He splits the darkness from the light,
divides the wrong from what is right.
No compromise in His decree—
only truth can set us free.
His blade cuts clean through bone and marrow,
straightens what is bent and narrow.

We sought a savior draped in calm,
who'd soothe our wounds with healing balm,
but found instead a raging storm,
who would our very souls transform.
He came to burn away the chaff,
to break in two our golden calf.

So tremble when you hear His name,
for comfort was not why He came.
He came to set the world on fire,
to raise the stakes, to take us higher.
On the scene comes Christ once more,
His sword still cutting as before.

Divine Insurgent

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
Not the passive, pallid face
painted meek with tender grace,
but revolutionary flame
burning systems built on shame.

He came to tear the temple down,
to strip the mighty of their crown.
He came to flip the money tables,
to rewrite all our ancient fables.
He came to challenge and disrupt,
to cleanse what time had corrupted.

His sword—a tongue that speaks the truth,
a voice that shakes the very roof
of institutions built on sand,
of doctrines no one understands.
He cuts through dogma, slices creed,
to plant instead a mustard seed.

So when you seek the gentle Christ,
remember too the one who sliced
through hypocrisy and greed,
who met our wants with what we need.
On the scene He stands today,
His sword still clearing paths away.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
Divine Reckoning

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
His eyes ablaze with righteous fire,
Judgment day, His sole desire.

The meek had suffered far too long,
The wicked prospered in their wrong.
No olive branch in gentle hand,
But steel to cleanse the tainted land.

He who once had turned the cheek,
Now stands before us, strong not meek.
The lamb transformed to lion's roar,
Bringing justice to the shore.

The temples built on greed and lies,
Crumble as the false god dies.
No sermon from the mount today,
Only swift and fierce display.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
To separate the wheat from chaff,
And cut in two our golden calf.

The Second Coming

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Trampling vineyards of men's wrath,
Cleaving darkness in His path.

He who once wore crown of thorn,
Now with lightning comes adorned.
Gentle shepherd set aside,
Judge and warrior now stride.

Those who twisted sacred word,
Find their empires now disturbed.
Mansions built on backs of poor,
Tremble at His mighty roar.

No more parables of grace,
Only truth laid bare, unveiled face.
Time for choosing now has passed,
Mercy's hour could not last.

The humble raised to heaven's height,
The proud cast down from lofty flight.
On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Justice hanging by His sword.

Revelation's Edge

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Splitting truth from crafted lies,
Tearing veils from blinded eyes.

We who sought a gentle king,
Find instead the reckoning.
He who bled upon the tree,
Returns to set the captives free.

Not through words of comfort sweet,
But iron striking concrete.
Breaking chains of old deceit,
Scattering the tares from wheat.

Who can stand on judgment day,
When mountains melt like wax away?
When He who once was crucified,
Now stands with vengeance at His side?

Yet in this terror hope remains,
For those who bear injustice's pains.
A world reborn through cleansing fire,
Rising from destruction's pyre.

On the scene comes Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

The Divine Division

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Not as babe in manger lay,
But as thunder on that day.

He divides as lightning strike,
Separating wrong from right.
No more sermons on the hill,
Only justice to fulfill.

We who sought a savior mild,
Meek and gentle as a child,
Find instead the Lion's roar,
Shaking heaven's very floor.

False prophets flee before His gaze,
As temples built on greed now raze.
Those who twisted sacred text,
Find themselves supremely vexed.

Yet in this sword of gleaming light,
A promise shines through darkest night:
After judgment, after pain,
A world where truth and justice reign.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

The Reckoning Blade

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Not in stable, meek and mild,
But as tempest, fierce and wild.

The dove has shed its gentle wings,
The lamb now roars as lion sings.
He who once blessed children small,
Now comes to judge both great and small.

The merchants scattered long ago,
From temples they had brought so low,
Now find no place to hide their face,
From piercing eyes of burning grace.

The sword He wields cuts clean and true,
Dividing old world from the new.
No longer bearing sins in pain,
But severing evil's deadly chain.

Yet even in this fearsome sight,
A promise glimmers in the night:
After justice has been done,
A kingdom comes, God's will be won.

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
The Divine Warrior

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Not the gentle shepherd's crook,
But lightning flashing from His look.

He came to cleave the truth from lies,
To rend the veil before our eyes.
Not passive love that turns the cheek,
But righteous fire for those who seek.

His blade cuts through our comfort's shell,
Dividing heaven, marking hell.
He severs bonds of old belief,
Brings revolution, not relief.

This Christ stands tall with blade held high,
Illuminating darkened sky.
Not meek and mild as we've been told,
But fierce and free and lightning-bold.

So face the edge of sacred steel,
Decide which wounds will hurt or heal.
For Christ came not to soothe our pain,
But cleanse our souls with holy flame.

Sword of Truth

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
A blade of justice, gleaming bright,
cutting through the darkest night.

Not the savior meek and mild
that mothers whisper to their child.
But fierce divinity unveiled,
before whom demons cowered, quailed.

He came to split the world in two—
those who'd follow, those who knew
the comfort of their gilded cage
was worth more than a prophet's rage.

His sword divides the false from true,
the ancient stories from the new.
It severs ties to former things,
and clips the edges of our wings.

So do not seek a gentle hand
from one who came to break this land,
who offers not tranquility
but revolution's liberty.

For Christ stands at the crossroads now,
his blade against your throat somehow,
and asks which side you're standing on—
before the final night is gone.

The Cleaving

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
Not olive branch but sharpened steel,
To cut away what will not heal.

He walks between the rows of men
Who built their temples once again
To gods of gold and gods of might—
He burns them down in holy light.

The meek shall never claim this earth
Until the sword has proved their worth.
The hungry never shall be filled
Until the corrupt blood is spilled.

He splits the darkness with His blade,
Divides the truth from masquerade.
No gentle Jesus, sweet and mild,
But righteous wrath and justice wild.

So stand before this sacred fire
And watch as all your vain desire
Is burned away like morning mist—
By sword and flame we are baptized.

For love without a cutting edge
Is merely sentiment, a pledge
That crumbles when the night grows cold.
Christ's sword makes broken spirits whole.

Division

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
Not to unite but to divide,
To tear the veil of truth from lies.

He stands between the dark and light,
His blade reflecting stars at night.
Not gentle savior, meek and mild,
But warrior fierce and undefiled.

He splits the father from the son,
The mother-daughter bond undone.
He severs ties of flesh and blood
For loyalty to something above.

The blade that cuts is double-edged—
It wounds the wielder, so it's said.
For even Christ bears scars that show
The price of truth we've come to know.

So do not seek a painless path
Or shelter from the holy wrath.
For love that never dares to wound
Is shallow comfort, falsely tuned.

The sword He brings is mercy strange,
A violent, necessary change.
It cuts away what cannot last
And frees the future from the past.

The Sword Bearer

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
not with peace but with a sword.
His eyes like flame, His voice like thunder,
Tearing complacency asunder.

Not gentle Jesus meek and mild,
But cosmic justice reconciled.
He came to set the captives free
By force of sacred alchemy.

The sword He wields is double-edged,
One side is truth, one side is pledge.
It cuts away deception's veil,
Reveals where human efforts fail.

The blood that flows is not from hate,
But surgery to separate
The cancer growing in our soul,
From parts that might again be whole.

So tremble not before His blade,
Unless in falsehood you have stayed.
For those who seek the painful truth
Find mercy in His sacred proof.

The sword of Christ is not for war,
But transformation at the core.
It slices through our practiced lies,
That something new might finally rise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On the scene came Christ The Lord, not with peace but with a sword.'

responses.text:
Divine Reckoning

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
His eyes aflame with righteous fire,
Judgment day—humanity's pyre.

Not the gentle shepherd's call,
But thunder that would shake the wall.
Dividing truth from falsehood's claim,
Cleaving souls—not all the same.

We sought a savior draped in light,
Who'd wash away our sins so bright.
Instead He came to separate
The worthy from the reprobate.

His sword cuts deep through flesh and bone,

Not comfort does He promise now,
But transformation, anyhow.

So stand before this sacred blade,
As ancient debts must now be paid.

When Christ decides what's false and true.

The Sword of Truth

On the scene came Christ The Lord,

Not to coddle, not to please,

Truth divides like sharpened steel,

Family torn by faith's demand,

We expected gentle grace,

This sword that pierces heart and mind

It separates the wheat from chaff,

So when you seek the Savior's face,

For love sometimes must cut to heal,
And truth must hurt before we kneel.

Revolution of the Lamb

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Revolution in His wake,
Empires tremble, systems break.

Not the meek and mild we praise
In our comfortable, churchly ways.
But the rebel king who came
To set the status quo aflame.

He divides the rich from poor,
Opened wide salvation's door.
Challenged power, questioned might,
Turned the darkness into light.

His sword—not metal, but His word—
The sharpest truth that's ever heard.
It cuts through lies we tell ourselves,
Through wealth we hoard on gilded shelves.

So follow if you dare this path,

The Divine Warrior

On the scene came Christ The Lord,
Not with peace but with a sword.
Not in robes of priestly white,
But armored for eternal fight.

Blood-red banner, justice raised,
Against the darkness, weapon blazed.
Not to comfort, not to soothe,
But to shake foundations, prove

That love sometimes must wear a face
Of fierce determination, grace
That cuts away what kills the soul—

The Prince of Peace with warrior's stance,

So tremble at this sacred sight:

The Sword of Division

On the scene came Christ The Lord,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:
THE SERPENT'S WHISPER

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of innocence surrendered to temptation's fatal spell.
Coiled around the branches in the garden's dappled light,
A forked tongue that whispered of forbidden delight.

Oh, how the fruit gleamed crimson in the Eden afternoon,
A knowledge-bearing vessel that would bring its wisdom soon.
But wisdom carries burdens that the innocent can't see,
And paradise was forfeit with one bite from that tree.

Now we wander distant from that perfect garden's gate,
Carrying the knowledge and the burden of our fate.
The serpent still is whispering in corners of our mind,
Of fruits we shouldn't taste and truths we shouldn't find.

The snake and the apple, ancient symbols intertwined,
Remind us how our freedom and our fall were both designed.
A sorry tale indeed, but one we needed to begin—
The human story written in that first, forbidden sin.

EDEN'S ECHO

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A narrative of choices that in shadow always dwell.
Beneath the Tree of Knowledge where the sunlight barely reached,
A covenant was broken, and a lesson harshly teached.

She held the fruit with wonder, felt its weight against her palm,
While serpent's words like honey broke the garden's sacred calm.
"Just one bite," it promised, "and your eyes will truly see."
The universe of knowledge—all that you were meant to be.

Perhaps the snake was wisdom in a form we couldn't bear,
Or maybe just the question that we always needed there.
For what is human greatness if not reaching for the light?
What glory in obedience without freedom's sacred right?

So when I see an apple, ripe and red upon the bough,
I think of all the knowledge that our kind has gathered now.
The snake and apple taught us that to grow is to rebel—
A sorry tale for some, perhaps, but one I'm proud to tell.

VENOM AND VIRTUE

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A dance of dark seduction where divinity once dwelled.
Scales that caught the sunlight as they slithered through the green,
The cleverest of creatures with intentions unforeseen.

Oh, crimson fruit of knowledge hanging heavy on the bough,
So innocent in purpose until serpent showed us how
To question our contentment, to imagine something more—
To open doors to worlds we never dreamed of before.

We call it fall from grace, this ancient choice of tooth and flesh,
But maybe it was rising—breaking free from ignorance's mesh.
For what is human nature but the courage to decide?
To taste both joy and sorrow with our eyes open wide?

So judge not harsh the serpent nor the woman nor the man,
For would you trade your knowing for an innocent command?
The snake and apple story is a mirror, can't you tell?
Of choices we make daily—heaven, knowledge, or our hell.

ORIGINAL SIN

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of paradise surrendered to deception's cunning spell.
In Eden's lush abundance where no sorrow dared to grow,
A reptile brought the questions we were never meant to know.

With scales like burnished emeralds and eyes of amber fire,
It wrapped around the branches, full of venomous desire.
The fruit hung ripe and ready, skin as red as morning light—
A beacon of temptation in the garden's pure delight.

One bite was all it took to shatter heaven's perfect plan,
The juice ran down her fingers as awareness first began.
The knowledge flooded swiftly—good and evil, shame and pride—
And suddenly the garden was no longer safe to hide.

Now thorns grow with our roses, sweat accompanies our bread,
And death waits at the ending of the path we all must tread.
The snake and apple haunt us through millennia of time,
A cautionary whisper of our ancestors' first crime.

FORBIDDEN WISDOM

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Though perhaps it's not as simple as the stories often sell.
For in that mythic garden where innocence held sway,
Perhaps there lurked a deeper truth about the light of day.

The serpent wasn't evil, just a creature born to see
Beyond the veil of ignorance to what we could yet be.
The apple not a sin but just the first courageous step
Toward consciousness awakened from its long, contented sleep.

Yes, paradise was forfeited, but what did we obtain?
The fire of understanding and the sacred gift of pain.
For what is growth but suffering transformed to something new?
What wisdom comes without the cost of seeing what is true?

So when you hear the story of the first forbidden fruit,
Consider that our banishment might be our greatest loot.
The snake and apple offered us the chance to truly dwell
As creators of our destiny—a sorry tale? Oh, well.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:
The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,

Coiled around the tree of knowledge bright,

Now we wander through this mortal coil,

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,

Humanity's first betrayal wasn't from a lover's kiss,

Yet who's to blame in this ancient myth?

Perhaps the tale speaks not of sin alone,

Of leaving safety for the vast unknown,

So when you see an apple, crimson bright,

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
But listen close, for there's more beneath the skin.
Not just of paradise and how we fell,

That slithering tempter with his forked tongue,
Not villain perhaps, but messenger instead.
The fruit of knowledge, ripe and freshly hung,
Awakened minds that innocence had kept fed.

What if this story isn't about shame?
But rather how we learned to truly see?
The price of wisdom carries heavy blame,
Yet grants the power to finally be free.

The garden walls that kept us safe inside,
Also kept us blind to greater truth.
Sometimes to grow, we need to cast aside
The comfortable constraints of sheltered youth.

So yes, the snake and apple brought us pain,
But also gave us art and love and thought.
Perhaps the loss was actually our gain—

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A metaphor that haunts our collective soul.
In corporate boardrooms where power-hungry dwell,
The same old story takes its modern toll.

That serpent now wears tailored suits with pride,
Whispering promises of wealth untold.
The apple gleams like golden stock inside
A market ripe for those both brave and bold.

We bite into technologies so sweet,
Never questioning what freedoms we might lose.
Our data harvested—our lives complete
With artificial comforts we can't refuse.

From Eden's garden to the digital age,
The pattern of temptation stays the same.
Turning each new chapter, page by page,
Different actors playing in the game.

So when you're offered something too divine,
Remember that old cautionary rhyme—
The snake and apple crossing space and time,
A warning echoed through the halls of time.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Yet I shall spin it differently tonight.
The serpent, misunderstood, under history's spell,

Consider how the coiled one might defend:
"I offered only truth when lies prevailed,
A chance to see beyond the garden's end,
To question why such knowledge was curtailed."

And what of Eve, portrayed as weakness bound?
Perhaps she was the bravest of them all,
Who dared to reach for wisdom profound,
Accepting both the rise and then the fall.

The apple—not a sin but revolution,

A necessary step in evolution,

So judge not harsh the snake who dared to speak,

For in that moment, strong replaced the weak,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:

One bite—the juice ran crimson down her chin,

Now here we stand, inheritors of shame,

Yet in our fallen state, we still can see

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,

The serpent, wise beyond its reptile years,

The apple's flesh, so crisp beneath her teeth,

So when you hear of Eden's fabled fall,

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,

That gleaming fruit, suspended from the bough,

To challenge what authorities proclaim,

Perhaps the serpent, coiled and much maligned,

The garden lost—but gained a wider world,
As consciousness unfurled and was unfurled.

So when we speak of apples, snakes, and fall,

Our science, art, and love of liberty

The scales that glimmered in the dappled light,

What hunger dwells within the human heart

Yet in this tale of disobedience sown,

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,

For what kind deity would plant a tree
Then punish those who sought to truly see?
What father sets before his child a treat
Then casts them out for daring once to eat?

Perhaps the snake was wisdom in disguise,
The apple truth that opened human eyes.
Perhaps the garden wasn't paradise,
But golden cage constructed to entice.

So when you hear of Eve's corrupting bite,
Consider if her act brought dark or light.
For in the pain of leaving Eden's shore,
Humanity found what it was made for.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,'

responses.text:
The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Of innocence surrendered to temptation's wicked spell.
In Eden's perfect garden where the light was always clear,
A serpent's tongue brought darkness and humanity's first tear.

Coiled around the branches of forbidden knowledge's tree,
The creature watched and waited for naivety to see.
An apple hung like rubies, ripe with secrets yet untold,
A simple fruit that carried both damnation and gold.

The woman reached with trembling hand toward that fateful bite,
Not knowing how her hunger would bring everlasting night.
And so we bear the burden of that ancient, primal choice—
The whispers of the serpent still echo in our voice.

Yet in this tale of falling, there's wisdom to be found:
In every human failing, redemption may abound.
For though we lost our garden to a reptile's crafty lie,
We gained the gift of knowing both the how and the why.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A narrative of wisdom wrapped in punishment as well.
Slithering through history with scales that catch the light,
The serpent bears our burdens through humanity's long night.

We blame the coiled tempter for our exile from the green,
Forget that in its counsel deeper truths could be seen.
The apple—not just fruit but possibility's first seed,
A knowledge beyond gardens, beyond innocence and need.

Perhaps the snake was freedom in disguise, misunderstood,
Delivering us questions when we thought all answers good.
And Eve, maligned for centuries as weakness personified,
Was really the first scientist who wouldn't be denied.

So spin again this story from the margins, not the throne,
Where God's voice isn't thunder but a whisper in the bone.
The snake and apple offer us a different truth to hear:
That sometimes disobedience makes consciousness appear.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
But listen to its echoes, where deeper meanings dwell.

In corporate boardrooms where ambition coils tight,
The modern serpent whispers of power, wealth, and might.
The apple gleams as bonus, promotion, corner suite—
A bite that promises glory but tastes of cold deceit.

In politics' grand garden where leaders claim to serve,
The snake of corruption shows its venomous curve.
The apple of authority, so shiny on display,
Consumes those who consume it at democracy's decay.

In digital Edens where we scroll through endless feeds,
The algorithm serpent understands our deepest needs.
The apple glows in blue light, addictive in its charm,
We bite and bite again despite its subtle harm.

The sorry tale continues through each age and every fall,
The snake and apple changing form but present in them all.
Perhaps salvation lies not in avoiding every tree,
But recognizing serpents when they slither up to thee.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
Beneath the tree of knowledge where innocence once fell.
I wonder at the judgment passed through centuries of time,
On creatures bound together in mythology sublime.

The apple—was it really such a terrible delight?
Or merely nature's offering, a gift of second sight?
The snake—was it the devil or wisdom in disguise?
A teacher of hard lessons that made humans truly wise?

I've tasted fruit forbidden in gardens of my own,
And found that after sweetness, bitter seeds were sometimes sown.
I've listened to the whispers of my own internal snake,
And followed where it led me, for curiosity's sake.

Perhaps the greatest sorrow in this ancient, mythic tale,
Is not that we were tempted or that we were doomed to fail,
But that we blame the apple and the serpent for our choice,
Instead of recognizing our own hunger, our own voice.

So let us tell this story new—not sorry, but profound:
In questioning and seeking, our humanity is found.

The snake and the apple is a sorry tale to tell,
A metaphor that binds us in its antiquated spell.
I dreamt I was the serpent, coiled beneath the leaves,
Watching human drama through my ancient, slitted eyes.

I saw the woman standing, contemplating cosmic law,
Her fingers gently tracing what no creature touched before.
I did not speak in cunning or with malice in my heart,
I simply asked the question that would tear the world apart.

"Why place the tree before you if its fruit you cannot taste?
Why fashion minds for wondering then leave them bound in waste?"
The apple hung between us—not a sin but simply this:
The courage to ask questions when ignorance is bliss.

God found us in the garden as the evening shadows fell,
Not angry at disobedience but knowing all too well
That once the mind has opened to the vastness of its scope,
No paradise can hold it—it must wander, fear, and hope.

So when you tell the story of the snake, the fruit, the fall,
Remember I'm the question mark inscribed upon your soul.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'On a lonely selection far out in the West'

responses.text:
On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the dust devils dance and the sun beats its chest,
A weathered old farmhouse stands silent and still,
Its windows like eyes gazing out from the hill.

The windmill creaks slowly, a metallic sigh,
As clouds drift like nomads across the vast sky.
The fence lines run straight to the edge of the world,
Where dreams and horizons are endlessly furled.

A horseman rides home as the light starts to fade,
His shadow stretched long by the day God has made.
The cattle move slowly through yellowing grass,
Time here is measured by seasons that pass.

This hardscrabble life etches lines on the face,
Of those who have chosen this desolate place.
Yet beauty resides in the stillness found here,
Where stars shine like diamonds when night draws near.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
A soul finds its purpose, a heart finds its rest.

On a lonely selection far out in the West
Where the red earth meets sky in a breathless caress,
I built my existence from nothing but hope,
With calloused hands and the strength to cope.

The eucalypts whisper when nobody's near,
Telling secrets of drought that return year to year.
The magpies carol at breaking of dawn,
As another day on this harsh land is born.

My nearest neighbor, ten miles away,
Counts as family in this wild display.
We share what we have when times become tough,
For out here, community is more than enough.

The night brings a silence so deep it can drown
All memories of chaos from life in the town.
The stars form a blanket that covers us all,
A cosmic reminder of how we stand small.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
I've found my belonging, my challenge, my quest.
Though isolation may seem like a curse to some souls,
In this vast empty landscape, my spirit runs whole.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the crows call at dawn and the sun burns the rest,
A woman stands watching the horizon's thin line,
Her face etched with stories of struggle and time.

She came as a bride to this unforgiving land,
With dreams in her heart and a ring on her hand.
The seasons rolled by like the clouds overhead,
As she birthed seven children on a flour-sack bed.

The drought took three harvests, the floods took one more,
Her husband's strong spirit broke during the war.
Yet still she persisted through grief and through pain,
Planting hope in dry furrows, awaiting the rain.

Her children now scattered like seeds in the wind,
Some flourished in cities, some never quite pinned.
But she stays on this land that has shaped who she is,
Her roots grown too deep for departing to cities.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
She's become like the gumtrees that never do rest.
Bending with hardship but never quite breaking,
A monument to endurance of her own making.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the dingoes howl secrets to stars never guessed,
I found myself standing 'tween heaven and earth,
A speck in the cosmos of infinite worth.

The spinifex whispers of ancestors past,
Aboriginal dreamings too sacred to last
In a world that moves forward with terrible haste,
Leaving wisdom of old ones to fade and to waste.

The billabong mirrors the indigo sky,
As cockatoos screech their impertinent cry.
The ancient rock paintings tell stories of old,
More precious than any discovery of gold.

This land has a spirit that speaks to the soul,
It breaks you apart, then it makes you whole.
It teaches through silence and terrible heat,
That surrender, not conquest, makes life complete.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
I learned what it means to be truly blessed.
Not with riches or fame that will tarnish with time,
But connection to country, both harsh and sublime.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the shadows grow long and mirages don't rest,
A boundary rider pauses, his horse breathing deep,
As the boundary between day and night starts to creep.

The fence stretches endless through mulga and stone,
A thin line of purpose in vastness unknown.
His swag and his billy, companions so true,
And memories of faces, now faded from view.

The stars are his compass, the wind is his clock,
The rhythm of hoofbeats on hard-baked rock
Beats time to the song of this desolate place,
Where distance is measured in silence and space.

He's witnessed the birth of lambs under the moon,
And death in the jaws of wild dogs too soon.
He's weathered the cyclones and blistering heat,
Found beauty in places where few dare to meet.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
He carries no burden of things unpossessed.
For freedom's his fortune in this timeless land,
Where a man's true worth lies in the strength of his hand.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,

A woman stands silent, her face to the wind,

The drought has been cruel for three years or more,

The sheep huddle weakly near dried-up dams,
While she counts every penny and every last lamb.

Her husband long gone to the city for work,
Leaving duties uncounted for her not to shirk.
The children still sleeping in beds worn but clean,

She turns to the homestead, paint peeling and spare,

On this lonely selection far out in the West,

On a lonely selection far out in the West,

Crows gather at dawn on the one surviving tree,

On this lonely selection far out in the West,

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the spinifex whispers of pioneers' quest,
I found an old journal, its pages stained brown,
With words from a woman who'd never seen town.

'Dear God,' she had written in trembling hand,
'The children are hungry, we can't work this land.
My husband grows silent with each passing day,
I fear that his mind is now wandering away.'

The ink had been tears on the very next page,
'The rains never came, and the well is now dry,
The cattle lie bloated where once they would graze,
Yet somehow we wake to face each new day.'

The final entry was but a single line,
'The mailman comes Tuesday. I'll send for help then.'
But Tuesday, it seems, never came to that place,
Where hope had been crushed by the land's harsh embrace.

On this lonely selection far out in the West,
I buried the journal and with it, the rest
Of dreams that had withered in unforgiving soil,
Yet somehow still whisper of courage and toil.

It's here, in this vastness, my soul can reside.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the spinifex whispers of times long ago,
A rusted tin shack leans against time's behest,
Its corrugated skin catching sunset's warm glow.

The boundary rider once called this place home,
His swag on the veranda, his dog at his feet.
The stock route nearby where the cattle would roam,
And the windmill that creaked with a rhythmic heartbeat.

No telephone hummed here, no lights pierced the dark,
Just kerosene lanterns and stars overhead.
The nearest neighbor's smoke was a faraway mark,
A day's ride at least, so the boundary rider said.

The waterholes shrink in the merciless heat,
While mirages dance on the shimmering plain.
The cycles of drought and of rain incomplete,
As nature plays games with the promise of rain.

This lonely selection, though barren it seems,
Holds stories of struggle, endurance, and will.
For out in the West, where men chased their dreams,
The spirit of pioneers lingers there still.

On a lonely selection far out in the West,
Where the horizon stretches like God's own line,
I watch as the sun sinks into its rest,
And the stars emerge in their grand design.

The dingo's howl is my evening bell,
The creek bed my garden, though dry as bone.
No church spire points to heaven or hell,
Just endless sky where wild birds have flown.

My sheep are scattered across the plain,
Tiny white dots on a canvas vast.
I pray each evening for generous rain,
To quench this thirst that seems built to last.

The mail comes rarely, the visitors less,
Yet solitude here is a friend, not foe.
The city's chaos and constant stress
Seem distant dreams from long ago.

My grandfather claimed this untamed land,
With nothing but courage and calloused hands.
Now I continue what he began,
A legacy written in dust and sand.

On this lonely selection far out in the West,
I've found my purpose, my truth, my home.
Though hardship tests me with every test,
I would not trade it for worlds unknown.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Shadows Within

Everyone has a fear, a darkness they keep close,
Locked in chambers of the heart where daylight seldom goes.
Some fear the crushing loneliness of empty rooms at night,
Others dread the crowded space where eyes burn too bright.

A mother fears her child's pain, a soldier fears no return,
A writer fears the empty page where no words will burn.
The brave man fears his courage lost, the wise fears being wrong,
The singer fears the silence when there's no more song.

We carry these companions through our winding days,
These spectral whispers guiding our hesitant ways.
Perhaps in sharing shadows, we find our common thread,
The universal tremble in the words left unsaid.

Everyone has a fear—this truth binds us all,
In this human journey where we stumble and fall.
Yet in our shared fragility, a strange strength appears,
When we acknowledge openly: everyone has fears.

The Universal Shadow

Everyone has a fear, it whispers in the night,
A personal demon, refusing to take flight.
The CEO in his tower fears irrelevance,
While the homeless man below fears permanence.

Fears like fingerprints, uniquely our own,
Yet universally human, to the marrow, to the bone.
The child fears monsters beneath the bed,
The elder fears memories fading from head.

Some fear the crash of thunder, the flash of storm,
Others the quiet routine, the mundane norm.
The artist fears the canvas blank and bare,
The lover fears their heart laid too bare.

We build our walls, our shields, our masks,
To hide these fears, our impossible tasks.
But what if instead we wore them like badges,
Proudly displaying our emotional damages?

Everyone has a fear—this truth connects our souls,
The common thread in our different roles.
For in acknowledging the tremble in our hands,
We find the courage to make our stands.

Whispers of Dread

Everyone has a fear, a shadow that follows,
Silent as midnight, deep as the hollows.
The businessman fears failure's bitter taste,
The explorer fears a life gone to waste.

The doctor fears the battle that can't be won,
The parent fears harm to their daughter or son.
The teacher fears minds that refuse to grow,
The farmer fears seasons that refuse to sow.

Some fears are ancient, primal and raw—
The darkness, the heights, the predator's jaw.
Others are modern, complex, refined—
Rejection, connection, the trials of the mind.

We carry these burdens like stones in our pockets,
Heavy and hidden, locked tight in our lockets.
Yet when we gather around fires at night,
Sharing our stories by flickering light,

The weight seems to lessen, the darkness recedes,
As fear shared becomes strength for our needs.
For everyone has a fear—this truth we all know,
And in this communion, our courage can grow.

The Shared Trembling

Everyone has a fear, a trembling inside,
A corner of darkness where monsters reside.
Some wear their fears like armor of steel,
Others like wounds that never quite heal.

The politician fears the truth coming clear,
The honest man fears when no one will hear.
The wealthy fear losing their golden towers,
The poor fear tomorrow's uncertain hours.

We fear the known—death's inevitable call,
We fear the unknown—perhaps most of all.
We fear connection, we fear being alone,
We fear being forgotten, we fear being known.

These fears like rivers run through our veins,
Unique in their courses, shared in their pains.
The child who fears monsters, the sage who fears time,
Both tremble the same when the clock starts to chime.

Perhaps there's a wisdom in naming our dread,
In speaking aloud what runs wild in our head.
For everyone has a fear—this truth sets us free,
In our shared vulnerability, we find unity.

Veiled Companions

Everyone has a fear, a private ghost,
A specter that haunts what we love the most.
The captain fears the ship will not withstand,
The desert wanderer fears the shifting sand.

We carry these phantoms through daylight hours,
Hiding them under smiles like wilting flowers.
The comedian jokes to mask his dread,
The insomniac fears the waiting bed.

Some fears are small—spiders upon the wall,
Others vast as oceans, ready to enthrall.
The speaker fears the silence of no applause,
The rebel fears fighting for a losing cause.

Yet in these terrors, strangely, we're not alone,
These shared vibrations connect flesh to bone.
The strongest among us, the weak, the wise,
All harbor secrets behind guarded eyes.

Perhaps courage isn't the absence of fear,
But walking forward with it, crystal clear.
For everyone has a fear—this truth we embrace,
Finds us all equal in this human race.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
SHADOWS WE CARRY

Everyone has a fear, a shadow that follows,
Silent companion through valleys and hollows.
Some fear the darkness when day turns to night,
Others the future that's not yet in sight.

A mother fears losing her child to the world,
A soldier, the moment when flags are unfurled.
The artist dreads canvas remaining pristine,
The lover fears words that remain unforeseen.

We carry these shadows like weights in our chest,
Some buried so deep we forget they exist.
Yet fear is the thread in our human design,
The whisper that tells us what's precious, what's mine.

So wear your fear proudly, acknowledge its voice,
For courage exists not in absence of choice,
But standing despite all the trembling inside,
Embracing the shadows we all try to hide.

THE UNIVERSAL TREMOR

Everyone has a fear that gnaws at their bones,
A private terror they face all alone.
Some shake at heights, some at depths of the sea,
Some fear the chains, while others, being free.

The businessman dreads the market's collapse,
The dreamer fears time as it slowly elapse.
The brave wear masks of unflinching resolve,
While underneath, anxieties evolve.

Fear is democracy's truest expression,
Granting each soul its unique apprehension.
It whispers in boardrooms and playground swings,
In palace halls and where the homeless sing.

Perhaps in sharing our trembling hearts,
We find the courage when the shaking starts.
For in our fear, we are never unique,
Just human souls, vulnerable and weak,
Yet somehow stronger when we dare to speak.

MONSTERS UNDER DIFFERENT BEDS

Everyone has a fear, tucked beneath their smile,
Hidden in corners that stretch mile after mile.
The child fears monsters with terrible teeth,
The adult, the monsters that lurk underneath

The surface of polite society's mask,
Of bills unpaid, of failing at each task.
The old man fears being forgotten in time,
The young girl fears her voice won't ever climb

Above the noise of those who speak too loud.
The rich man fears becoming unendowed,
The poor man fears he'll never rise at all.
Some fear the spring, while others fear the fall.

Yet in these fears that seem to separate,
Lies common ground on which we navigate.
For fear itself is not what makes us weak—
It's what we do when knees begin to creak,
And how we rise when courage seems so bleak.

THE INVISIBLE CHAINS

Everyone has a fear, a chain they cannot see,
Wrapped around their spirit, longing to break free.
Some fear abandonment, empty rooms at night,
Others fear success and standing in the light.

Fear wears different faces through the passing years,
Changing its disguise as clarity appears.
The child fears monsters lurking in the dark,
The adult fears leaving no remaining mark.

We build our lives around these silent dread,
Construct defenses for the path ahead.
Some build walls so high they touch the sky,
Others wear their armor in a watchful eye.

But what if fear is not our enemy?
What if it's a teacher of what's meant to be?
Perhaps in trembling hands and racing heart,
We find the courage to at last depart
From safety's shore to where we're meant to start.

COMMON THREAD

Everyone has a fear that binds us tight,
A thread through humanity, dark as night.
The scholar fears ignorance will prevail,
The sailor fears when winds fill not his sail.

The doctor fears the wound she cannot heal,
The judge fears justice he cannot reveal.
The farmer fears the drought that kills his grain,
The poet fears her words poured out in vain.

In mansions grand and hovels made of tin,
Fear visits all, no matter what's within.
It crosses borders, speaks in every tongue,
Resounds in hearts of old and very young.

Yet in this fear that seems to separate,
A bridge is built where we communicate.
For when I see your trembling, shaking form,
I recognize the shadow of my storm,
And reach across the darkness we both know,
To hold your hand—and neither lets it go.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
SHADOWS WE CARRY

THE UNIVERSAL TREMOR

Some fears wear masks of reason, others none—
The irrational terror of open spaces,
The logical dread of climate's changing faces,
The midnight worry for a wayward son.

We hide them in our pockets, these secret things,

Perhaps our shared vulnerability
Is not our weakness but our strongest tie—
The trembling thread that binds humanity
As we face together what makes us cry.

WHAT KEEPS US AWAKE

Everyone has a fear, a monster beneath the bed,
A specter that follows through waking hours,
Silent in daylight, roaring when stars appear.

The child fears abandonment,
The lover fears indifference,
The artist fears the empty page,
The aged fear forgetting names of those they cherish most.

We carry these burdens like lockets against our hearts,
Sometimes forgetting they're there
Until something triggers the latch
And out spills everything we've tried to contain.

How strange that what terrifies me
Might make you laugh,
While your nightmares seem trivial through my eyes.
Yet the feeling—that tightness of chest,
That quickening pulse—speaks a universal language.

Perhaps in acknowledging our fears,
We find not weakness but connection,
Not isolation but a bridge
Across the chasms that divide us.

THE EQUALIZER

Everyone has a fear, a trembling within,
A private earthquake that others cannot see.
The brave soldier startles at sudden noise,
The confident speaker dreads the silent room.

Fear: the great equalizer of human souls,
No wealth can purchase its absence,
No wisdom entirely dispel its shadow,
No strength fully shield against its touch.

Some fears are ancient as our species—
Darkness, heights, the unknown lurking beyond.
Others born of modern circumstance—
Connection lost, privacy invaded, time accelerating.

We craft elaborate disguises,
Pretending invulnerability in public spaces,
While in private moments, we acknowledge
The quivering creature beneath our skin.

Perhaps true courage isn't fearlessness
But recognition of our common fragility—
The understanding that across all divides,
We share this fundamental human truth.

UNIVERSAL WHISPERS

Everyone has a fear, like fingerprints unique,
Yet universal in their power to unmake us.

The mountain climber dreads not heights

The celebrated author stares at blank pages,
Terrified that yesterday's words were the last
The universe would grant her trembling hands.

The father watches his child's first steps,
Heart suspended between joy and the dread
Of all the ways the world might harm this love.

We carry these fears like secret identities,
Hidden beneath professional smiles,
Beneath confident handshakes and casual conversation.

But in the democracy of night,
When sleep eludes and thoughts circle like vultures,
We are equalized by this human condition—
The knowledge that something exists
With power to shatter our carefully constructed worlds.

Perhaps in this shared vulnerability
Lies our greatest strength.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Everyone has a fear'

responses.text:
Everyone has a fear

SHADOWS WE CARRY

My grandmother feared birds, their sudden wings,

Another dreads the silence between breaths.

I've watched strong men crumble at hospital doors,
Brave women falter at a certain shade of blue.
Our fears—unique fingerprints of soul—
Reveal more truth than any pride we hold.

Perhaps our fears are maps to who we are,
The shadows we carry from ancient stars.

UNIVERSAL TREMBLING

Everyone has a fear, a trembling deep inside,
Like autumn leaves that quiver before they fall.
I've seen warriors weep at thunder's call
And scholars dread the questions they can't hide.

My mother feared the ocean's endless reach,
Though desert-born, she knew its pull by name.
My lover fears forgetting, the slow decay of brain,
The memories of us washing out like tide on beach.

We wear our courage like armor, polished bright,
But underneath, our fears tap morse code on bone.
They whisper: you are fragile, you are not stone,

Perhaps our fears connect us more than joy—

THE SHARED BURDEN

Everyone has a fear

Some rational, some bizarre
But all equally potent.

The businessman fears bankruptcy
While his daughter fears the dark
The swimmer fears the endless deep
The artist fears the empty mark.

I fear the slow extinction of bees
You fear planes that never land
She fears the silence after goodbye
He fears the trembling of his hand.

Our fears—like fingerprints—unique
Yet universal in their grip
They bind us in a common thread
This human fellowship.

So when you shake beneath your fear
Remember this one truth:
The bravest heart is not fearless
But one that trembles, and moves through.

WHISPERS OF MORTALITY

Everyone has a fear, a private haunting,

The child fears monsters beneath wooden beds,

I've catalogued fears like collecting strange insects:
The fear of never being truly seen,

Perhaps our fears are just whispers of mortality,
The body's wisdom warning: treasure this.
For in our trembling lies our greatest truth—
What terrifies reveals what matters most.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!'

responses.text:
Fire up the Sky

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Celestial canvas painted bright,
With trails of human ambition,
Reaching past the veil of night.

Metal dragons breathing flame,
Pushing past Earth's jealous hold,
Leaving gravity's chains behind,
As ancient stories long foretold.

Upward, upward, never ceasing,
Breaking through the atmosphere,
Where stars await our brief hello,
As we approach their realm so clear.

Each ember in the cosmic dark,
A testament to dreams unleashed,
When minds of science and wonder merge,
And boundaries are finally breached.

So fire up the sky, brave rockets,
Carry hopes beyond blue dome,
Write our story in the heavens,
Make the universe our home.

Cosmic Ignition

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Watch as they pierce the twilight veil,
Tiny stars of human making,

We send our dreams on wings of steel,
To dance among the ancient light.

The children point with wide-eyed wonder,
As heaven's curtain burns away,
Revealing pathways never traveled,
Where only brave souls dare to stray.

Each burst of light, a question answered,
Each plume of smoke, a challenge met,
The universe no longer distant,

So let us launch these fiery beacons,
Let science soar on passion's wings,
And celebrate this human marvel—
The joy that exploration brings.

Ignition of Dreams

These metal angels climb and soar,

The countdown echoes in my chest,

As we collectively hold breath,
For journeys leaving Earth behind.

The children of tomorrow's dawn

A neighbor waiting to be touched,
A destiny approaching sooner.

So fire the engines, break the chains,
Let thunder crack the peaceful blue,
For in each launch we see ourselves—
What human spirit can push through.

The universe awaits our knock,
Its secrets patient to be found,
In rocket sparks that light the dark,

Ascension

Fire up the sky with rocket sparks!
Climbing columns of defiance,
Against the pull of Mother Earth,
A marriage of courage and science.

Thunder rolls across the plain,

What ancient gods would think of us?

Each mission born from countless hours,

Through troubled, bloody years.

So watch the flames that lick the clouds,

In rocket sparks, our future flies,

For we were never meant to crawl,

Humanity's most brilliant page.

Skyward Symphony

The launchpad trembles, Earth exhales,

We stand as witnesses to power,

Directed upward, ever upward,
Where boundaries fall apart.

How strange to think that we were once
Just tribes who gazed at distant spheres,
Now sending messengers of hope
To pierce the veil of cosmic years.

The children watching will remember

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge in the darkest night,
When stars have fled and hope seems gone,
You are my ever-present light.

In valleys deep where shadows crawl,
And mountains high where winds may roar,
Your love surrounds me like a wall,
A fortress strong forevermore.

My parched soul thirsts for You, O Lord,
Like desert sands await the rain.
I find my peace in Your sweet word,
Your promise soothes my every pain.

When morning breaks across the sky,
And when the sun sinks in the west,
Upon Your name my lips rely,
In You alone my heart finds rest.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure compares to Thee.
Your mercy-seat becomes my throne,
Your grace has set my spirit free.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other power can claim my soul.
Through tempest waves and thunder's groan,
Your hand alone can make me whole.

I wander through this mortal plane,
A pilgrim seeking sacred light.
Through joy and sorrow, ease and pain,
You guide my steps through day and night.

The world offers its fleeting gold,
Its hollow praise and tarnished crown.
But I have treasures yet untold
In Your love that will not cast down.

When doubts assail like winter frost,
And faith seems but a dying flame,
I count all earthly wisdom lost
And cling more tightly to Your name.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My first love and my final breath.
Until I stand before Your throne,
I'll praise You through both life and death.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
The anchor in my shifting sea,
When waves of doubt have violently grown,
You whisper peace and calm to me.

I've searched the corners of this earth,
Tasted pleasures sweet and rare,
But nothing holds eternal worth
Except the moments in Your care.

The morning dew upon the grass,
The sunset painting crimson skies,
Reminds me as the seasons pass,
Your artistry before me lies.

In silence of the midnight hour,
When sleep eludes my restless mind,
I feel the presence of Your power,
A gentle touch, so soft and kind.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant on some far-off shore,
But dwelling in this heart of stone,
Transforming it forevermore.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not fashioned by my human hands,
Nor born from philosophic tone,
But Lord of seas and sky and lands.

Before the mountains found their place,
Before the oceans knew their shore,
You dwelled in everlasting grace,
And shall when time exists no more.

Yet You, the Infinite, draw near
To one as finite as am I.
You count my every falling tear
And hear each soft and broken sigh.

What mystery this love divine,
That bridges heaven's vast expanse!
You make Your holy dwelling mine,
Not by my merit, but Your chance.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not one among a pantheon vast,
But sovereign on Your rightful throne,
My first pursuit and final rest.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No idol shares Your sacred space.
My heart, once cold as carven stone,
Now warms beneath Your saving grace.

The desert of my soul once dry,
Now blooms with flowers of delight.
For You have heard my desperate cry
And turned my darkness into light.

When enemies surround my path,
And friends have turned their gaze away,
You shield me from impending wrath,
And guide me toward the breaking day.

The wealth of kings could never buy
The peace that flows from Your embrace.
The wisdom of the age can't vie
With one small glimpse of Your dear face.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My beginning and my end complete.
Until at last before Your throne,
I lay my crown at Your dear feet.

When desert winds scorch barren lands,
