I feel the comfort of Your hands,
Your living waters make me whole.

In valleys deep where shadows dwell,
When enemies surround my path,
Your rod and staff the fears dispel,
Protecting me from righteous wrath.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure claims my heart,
For in Your presence, fully known,
I find the peace that won't depart.

From morning's light to evening's rest,
My lips shall praise Your holy name,
For in Your love, I'm truly blessed,
And in Your grace, I stake my claim.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other power shall I seek.
Through tempests wild and skies unknown,
Your voice breaks through when I am weak.

The world offers its tarnished gold,
Its fleeting joys and hollow praise.
But You, my Lord, my soul does hold
Secure through all my numbered days.

When doubt creeps in like morning mist,
And faith seems but a distant shore,
I remember Your covenant kiss,
And trust in You forevermore.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My compass in this wilderness.
The seed of hope that You have sown
Blooms even in my deep distress.

So let my life be worship true,
A living psalm, a sacred song.
For all I am belongs to You,
To You, my God, I sole belong.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other throne my heart shall claim.
In wilderness and paths unknown,
My parched lips whisper Your name.

Like morning dew on desert sand,
Your mercy falls upon my days.
The universe, formed by Your hand,
Yet You attend to one who prays.

When darkness threatens to consume,
And doubt encircles like a shroud,
Your light dispels the gathering gloom,
Your strength lifts me above the crowd.

The mountains may dissolve to dust,
The oceans drain from shore to shore,
But in Your promise I will trust,
Your steadfast love forevermore.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My portion, shield, and great reward.
Before creation's cornerstone,
You knew my name, my King, my Lord.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Each breath I take bears witness true.
Not in cathedrals made of stone,
But in my heart, I worship You.

When sorrow weighs like leaden skies,
And joy seems but a memory faint,
You catch each teardrop as it flies,
And hear the whispers of my plaint.

The cosmos sings Your glory bright,
Yet You attend my humble prayer.
In darkest hour or morning light,
I find You present everywhere.

The world may offer wealth untold,
Or fame that flickers like a flame.
But You give peace that won't grow cold,
And grace that puts all else to shame.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My Alpha and Omega, too.
From dust You raised me, flesh and bone,
To dust I'll fall, returning to You.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly idol shares Your place.
Through barren lands where I have grown,
I've tasted Your sustaining grace.

When dawn breaks golden on the hills,
Or midnight veils the silent sky,
Your presence all creation fills,
Yet dwells within my heart's reply.

The world's cacophony grows loud,
Its siren songs entice and call,
But in Your shadow, humbly bowed,
I find the truth surpassing all.

When doubt and fear like giants loom,
And faith seems fragile as the dew,
Your Spirit enters every room,
Reminding me I belong to You.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My anchor in life's raging sea.
In You I live, in You I'm known,
In You I find identity.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge in the darkest night,
When shadows fall and hope seems gone,
You are my ever-burning light.

In valleys deep where fears abound,
When voices whisper of despair,
Your presence lifts me from the ground,
I feel your love beyond compare.

My soul thirsts for your living stream,
As deserts long for heaven's rain,
Your mercy flows in endless theme,
Washing away my doubt and pain.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No earthly treasure holds my heart,
You've claimed this spirit as your own,
From you I'll never wish to part.

When morning breaks with golden hue,
My praise will rise on wings of song,
For all my days belong to you,
In you, at last, I do belong.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other name my heart can claim.
Amid the cosmos, vast, unknown,
You whisper softly my true name.

The ancient stars that pierce the dark
Were fashioned by your mighty hand.
Yet closer than my breath you mark
The path my feet must understand.

When tempests rage and mountains shake,
When certainties dissolve like dew,
The ground beneath may crack and break,
But still my soul belongs to you.

In silence deep as ocean's floor,
In clamor loud as city streets,
You meet me at my spirit's door,
Where faith and doubt so often meet.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My first love and my final peace.
The seed from which my life has grown,
The grace in which all strivings cease.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not fashioned from my human need,
Nor conjured when I feel forlorn,
But present ere my soul could plead.

Before the mountains found their height,
Before the seas embraced the shore,
Before the sun first cast its light,
You were, and are, forevermore.

Yet paradox of mysteries—
This boundless God who spans all time
Would stoop to hear my whispered please,
And count my fragile heart as shrine.

What language can contain this truth?
What metaphor could hope to hold
The ageless one who grants me youth,
The fire that burns but leaves no coal?

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not one among competing powers,
But ground of being, cornerstone,
Eternity that touches hours.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Through wilderness and fertile plain,
In crowded halls and rooms of stone,
In laughter's dance and beds of pain.

When dawn arrives with rosy hue
And birdsong fills the waking air,
My thoughts, like arrows, fly to You,
Find target in Your loving care.

When noon burns hot with blinding light,
And shadows shrink beneath my feet,
You are the cloud that shields from might
Of sun that otherwise would beat.

When evening spreads its purple cloak
Across the sky's cathedral dome,
Your stars, like scattered silver, evoke
The promise that I'm not alone.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant force or abstract thought,
But intimate as marrow-bone,
The love by which I'm kept and sought.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No idol shares your sacred space.
No temple built of wood or stone
Can fully hold your boundless grace.

I sought you in the crowded square,
In wisdom's halls and pleasure's den,
Only to find you waiting where
My journey first did once begin.

Within this heart, so often torn
Between the world and heaven's call,
Your voice, like gentle breeze at dawn,
Reminds me you transcend it all.

What foolishness to wander far
When you were nearer than my breath!
What blindness not to see the star
That guided me through living death!

O God! Thou art my God alone;
This truth outlasts earth's fleeting days.
Before creation's cornerstone,
You were, and are, my endless praise.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'O God! Thou art my God alone;'

responses.text:
O God! Thou art my God alone;
My refuge when storms arise,
My shelter when all else has flown,
My compass 'neath darkened skies.

In valleys deep where shadows dwell,
Thy presence lights my way.
When doubts like crashing waves do swell,
Thy voice bids them to stay.

No earthly throne can match Thy might,
No crown outshine Thy grace.
Thy love, a never-fading light,
Illumines every place.

When I am lost in wilderness,
When paths before me blur,
Thou art the hand that guides me still,
The hope that makes me sure.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My first and final breath.
My joy in life, my peace in death,
My everlasting rest.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
No other claim I seek.
In vastness of creation shown,
Yet found when I am weak.

The universe bends to Thy will,
Stars dance at Thy command,
Yet in my heart, so small and still,
Thou makest Thy holy stand.

What miracle is this I find?
The Maker of all things
Would stoop to heal this troubled mind
And give my spirit wings.

Through desert lands my feet may tread,
Through waters deep and wide,
I fear no evil, know no dread,
With Thee, my God, beside.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
My beginning and my end.
The sacred mystery I've known,
My Father, Savior, Friend.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not fashioned from my need,
Nor conjured when I feel forlorn,
But present in each seed.

The whisper in the autumn leaves,
The thunder of the tide,
The silence when the daylight leaves,
In all, Thou dost abide.

I sought Thee in cathedrals vast,
In rituals old and new,
Yet found Thee in my breath at last,
More close than I e'er knew.

What folly that I searched so far
For what was always near,
More intimate than my own heart,
More real than my fear.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not one among the many.
Eternal truth I've always known,
Yet somehow failed to see.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Amidst the chaos of my mind,
When fractured thoughts have grown
And peace seems hard to find.

The world with all its glittering charms
Becomes but fading dust,
When I am folded in Thy arms
In perfect, sacred trust.

I've wandered through the marketplace
Of philosophies and creeds,
Yet only in Thy fierce embrace
Found answer to my needs.

When night descends with crushing weight
And doubts like specters loom,
Thy light becomes the narrow gate
That leads me from the tomb.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not distant, cold, removed,
But in my marrow, blood, and bone,
The lover and beloved.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
A truth both old and new,
Like ancient mountains, firmly grown,
Yet fresh as morning dew.

I've chased the shadows of this earth,
The pleasures quick to fade.
I've measured life by worldly worth,
And found myself betrayed.

But in the hollow of defeat,
When all my pride was gone,
I found Thee waiting, still and sweet,
As patient as the dawn.

How strange that in surrender's hour,
True freedom I should gain.
In weakness, I discovered power;
In sorrow's depths, Thy reign.

O God! Thou art my God alone;
Not earned but freely given.
The greatest love that I have known,
My earth and my heaven.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind Life and Remember

Time spirals backward like an ancient film,
Frames flickering through the projector of mind.
I watch myself at seven, scraped knees and wild,
Then sixteen, heart-broken, tears falling blind.

If I could grasp those moments once again,
Hold them like pebbles, smooth within my palm,
Would I change paths at crossroads long since passed?
Or simply breathe deeper in moments of calm?

Memory is selective, a curator biased,
Preserving joy more vividly than pain.
Yet even in darkness, lessons shimmer bright,
Like stars that only show when daylight wanes.

So rewind life and remember it all—
The laughter, the sorrow, the rise and the fall.

Echoes of Yesterday

Rewind life and remember the paths we once walked,
Footprints in sand now washed by time's tide.
Sunset conversations where promises were made,
Whispers and secrets, nothing to hide.

Rewind life and remember first kisses and last,
The trembling fingers, the thundering heart.
The weight of decisions we carried like stones,
The bridges we built, the ones torn apart.

In memory's garden, moments bloom eternal,
Preserved in amber, suspended in light.
Some sharp as thorns that still draw blood,
Others soft as petals on a summer night.

Rewind life and remember who we were before,
Before disappointment carved lines on our face.
Before wisdom was earned through trials by fire,
When the future stretched out with infinite grace.

Time's Ribbon

If I could pull time's ribbon backward through my hands,
Unraveling days like yarn from a sweater worn thin,
I'd pause at moments that slipped by too fast—
The last time my grandmother called me 'child',
The final summer before we all scattered like seeds.

Rewind life and remember:
The taste of rain on outstretched tongue,
The weight of books carried home from school,
The sound of keys in the door announcing 'home'.

Memories collect like dust in forgotten corners,
Until some stray thought stirs them into dancing light.
We are archives of our own history,
Libraries with shelves that bow beneath
The weight of everything we've ever been.

Rewind life and remember
That you are the sum of every version of yourself—
The child with skinned knees,
The teenager with fierce dreams,
The adult learning to forgive it all.

Retrograde Motion

Rewind life and remember—
How the stars looked from your childhood bedroom window,
Constellation maps unfurled across your ceiling.
How your mother's voice sounded before time weathered it,
Singing lullabies that carved themselves into your bones.

Rewind the cassette tape of existence,
Pause at the moments that made you:
The first heartbreak that taught you resilience,
The kindness from strangers that restored faith,
The mistakes that sculpted wisdom from naivety.

Memory is a time machine with faulty wiring,
Jumping between decades without warning,
Blurring faces that once were crystal clear,
Sharpening insignificant details to painful precision.

Yet in this retrospective journey,
We find the threads that weave our present cloth.
Rewind life and remember—
Not to dwell in bygone days,
But to recognize how far you've traveled,
Carrying the light of all you've been.

The Archaeology of Self

Rewind life and remember:
Dig through layers of yourself,
A personal archaeology.
Brush dust from artifacts of memory,
Catalog each fragment with trembling hands.

Here lies the yellow dress from third grade,
The bicycle crash that left a scar like a crescent moon,
The first letter signed with love,
The funeral where you finally understood absence.

In this excavation of years,
We uncover versions of ourselves
Preserved in amber moments,
Frozen in time's permafrost.

Some memories resist unearthing—
Roots grown too deep,
Too painful to extract without tearing present soil.
Others rise eagerly to the surface,
Buoyant as laughter bubbling up from forgotten wells.

Rewind life and remember:
You are both the digger and the found,
The seeker and the buried treasure,
The story and its patient listener.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind Life and Remember

Time's reel unspools in reverse,
Frames flickering like autumn leaves,
I watch younger versions emerge
From the shadows of memory's eaves.

A child's laughter, pure and sweet,
First love's tender, trembling kiss,
The ground beneath uncertain feet,
Moments we too quickly dismiss.

If I could grasp that silver thread,
Pull back the curtain of the years,
Revisit words left unsaid,
Rediscover joy beneath the tears.

Perhaps the beauty lies not in return,
But in the gentle act of reflection,
To hold each memory, discern
The patterns of our soul's direction.

So rewind life and remember well,
Not to dwell in days gone by,
But to gather wisdom's spell
And weave it through our present sky.

Echoes of Yesterday

Press rewind on the cassette of time,
Dust-covered memories come alive.
Snapshots frozen in mental shrine,
Moments when we truly thrived.

Remember the touch of grandmother's hand,
Wrinkled roadmaps of a journey long.
Remember first steps on foreign land,
The nervous tremble of a debut song.

In backward motion, see the tears
Transform to laughter, pain to bliss.
Reverse the accumulation of years,
Reclaim what time made us dismiss.

The child you were still lives within,
Hidden beneath adult disguise.
Rewind to find where you begin,
Before the world made you compromise.

In remembering lies our power to heal,
To understand the path we've walked.
These ghosts of moments, phantom-real,
Teach lessons time has never stalked.

So rewind life and remember true,
Not just the joy but also strife.
For in this retrospective view,
We find the meaning of our life.

The Reel of Memory

If I could rewind life like vintage film,
Frame by frame through yellowed light,
I'd pause on moments at the brim
Of significance, now clear in hindsight.

The playground where I skinned my knee,
Mother's cool hand upon my brow,
The oak tree where I carved a plea
For time to slow, not knowing how

Quickly seasons would dissolve to years,
Years to decades, swift as morning dew.
Remembrance now through misty tears
Reveals a self I barely knew.

To remember is to resurrect
Ghosts of choices, roads untaken,
To hold each fragment with respect,
Even those that left us shaken.

Perhaps we're meant to play this game,
Rewind, remember, then release,
Not clinging to joy or blame,
But finding in each frame some peace.

So I'll turn the handle of this ancient reel,
Watch shadows dance on memory's wall,
And in this gentle backwards feel,
Find gratitude for having lived at all.

Temporal Archaeology

I dig through layers of myself,
Archaeologist of my own time,
Brushing dust from memory's shelf,
Uncovering treasures, yours and mine.

Rewind the clock, peel back the years,
Excavate the child who knew no fear,
Before experience brought its tears,
Before the world made paths unclear.

Remember the taste of summer rain,
Bare feet on grass still warm from sun,
The sweet relief of absence of pain,
The weightlessness of being young.

In this remembering we find
The threads that weave our present cloth,
The patterns we were once blind
To see amid life's frantic froth.

Perhaps in rewinding we don't retreat
But rather gather strength to face
Tomorrow's challenges we meet,
Armed with wisdom, time can't erase.

So let us rewind, remember, reflect,
Not to escape our current day,
But to collect, connect, resurrect
The essence of who we are, come what may.

Memory's Carousel

Life spins forward, relentless wheel,
But in quiet moments between breaths,
I press rewind, and suddenly feel
The presence of what time forgets.

Remember the scent of grandfather's pipe,
Smoke rings dancing toward ceiling beams,
Remember the orchard, fruit ripe,
Summer days bursting at the seams.

The first heartbreak's crushing weight,
The triumph when fears were overcome,
How certain moments seem to wait
For us to circle back, to come

Home to them, older now and wise,
To understand their hidden gift.
Rewind and see through clearer eyes
How each experience caused a shift.

Memory—not a chain that binds
But wings that lift us toward the light,
The sacred space where one finds
Perspective's gentle, healing sight.

So rewind life and remember well,
Not to dwell in what cannot change,
But to hear what stories tell
About the soul's expanding range.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind Life and Remember

If I could pull the thread of time backward,
Unravel the tapestry of years spent,
I'd pause at moments now blurred and fractured,
And breathe them in until my soul was bent
With the weight of perfect recollection.

The first kiss beneath that summer willow,
My father's hands teaching mine to fish,
The last words my grandmother whispered,
A child's laughter—pure as a wishbone wish.

Memory fails us in our forward march,
Dulling edges of our sharpest joys,
Blurring faces we swore we'd never forget,
Muting voices once clear as silver noise.

So I gather fragments like precious stones,
Polishing each one against my heart,
For to rewind life and remember
Is to keep ourselves from falling apart.

Echoes of Yesterday

Rewind life and remember—
That sacred command haunts me at midnight,
When shadows play across my ceiling
And time feels thin as gossamer.

I reach backward through darkness,
Fingertips grazing moments I thought lost:
The ocean salt on my twelve-year-old lips,
My mother's perfume on Christmas morning,
The weight of my newborn child against my chest.

How strange that we live forward
But understand backward,
Collecting memories like seashells
Only to find them weathered, changed,
Transformed by the tides of perception.

To rewind is to resurrect,
To breathe life into ghosts,
To hold contradictions in open palms—
Joy and grief, triumph and regret,
All spinning in the carousel of remembrance.

Perhaps this is our truest inheritance:
Not what happened, but what we carry,
The stories we tell ourselves
As we rewind life and remember.

Time's Ribbon

Rewind life and remember—
Pull back the curtain of now,
Unwind the spool of moments
That brought you to this breathing hour.

See how the light caught her hair
That autumn day by the river?
How your hands trembled
When you first held something precious?
How the rain sounded different
Before you knew what loss was?

Memory is not a faithful servant
But a painter with wild brushstrokes,
Adding colors that weren't there,
Erasing details we swore to keep.

Still, we press rewind,
Again and again,
Searching for clues to ourselves,
For the path that led us here,
For proof that we have lived.

In this rewinding, we become archeologists
Of our own buried civilizations,
Unearthing artifacts of joy and pain,
Dusting off moments that shaped us,
Remembering not just what was,
But who we were when it happened.

The Reel of Remembrance

If memories were films on ancient reels,
I'd be the projectionist night after night,
Rewinding life through mechanical wheels,
Watching shadows dance in flickering light.

Rewind life and remember the scenes
That play behind closed eyelids when I dream:
First bicycle ride, skinned knees still stinging,
Grandfather's hands, calloused but forgiving.

Rewind life and remember the taste
Of summer berries stolen from neighbor's vines,
The crushing weight of teenage heartbreak,
The exquisite joy of crossing finish lines.

But memory's projector often fails,
Distorting images once crystal clear.
What's truth and what's invented in these tales
We tell ourselves about the yesteryear?

Perhaps it matters not what truly was,
But how these reels have shaped our very cores.
For in remembering, we find ourselves—
The heroes, villains, and all we've stood for.

So rewind life and remember well,
Each frame a gift, each scene a sacred spell.

Retrograde Motion

Rewind life and remember:
The universe began as a whisper
And so did you.

Imagine time as water—
Not flowing forward in a determined stream
But as an ocean where moments
Rise and fall like tides,
Where yesterday can touch tomorrow
In the sacred space of memory.

What would you see
If you could press that cosmic button?
The day you learned to trust your wings?
The night you realized stars die too?
The morning you finally understood
Your mother's silence?

We are not just who we are
But who we've been—
A collection of selves
Stacked like Russian dolls,
Each containing the echo
Of a laugh, a tear, a revelation.

To rewind life and remember
Is not to live in the past
But to acknowledge how it lives in us,
How we carry every version of ourselves
In this continuous present,
This eternal now
Where all time exists at once.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind Life and Remember

If I could pull time backward through my fingers,
Like cassette tape spun against its will,
I'd pause at moments where your laughter lingers,
And watch the light dance on the windowsill.

Memories cascade like autumn leaves,
Some vibrant still, some faded brown,
The tapestry that memory weaves
Holds fragments of a younger, distant town.

I'd trace the scars that made me who I am,
Revisit joys I didn't treasure then,
The simple days before the world began
To shape my heart with loss and grief again.

Rewind, replay, remember, and release—
The past remains both wound and masterpiece.

TEMPORAL ECHOES

Rewind life and remember:
Dust motes dancing in grandmother's kitchen,
The weight of father's hand upon my shoulder,
First kisses tasting of uncertainty and promise.

Rewind life and remember:
The clock's hands spinning counterclockwise,
Undoing heartbreaks, unmaking mistakes,
Unlearning lessons carved in bone.

Rewind life and remember:
The roads not taken shimmer like mirages,
Alternate selves wave from distant shores,
Ghosts of possibilities haunt every choice unmade.

Rewind life and remember:
Each moment contains infinity,
Each memory distorts with every recall,
We are archaeologists of our own histories,
Digging through layers of self-deception.

Rewind life and remember:
There is no going back, only forward,
Carrying the past like precious stones in our pockets.

Retrospection

Rewind life and remember—
The child with skinned knees and fearless eyes,
Who believed in magic and midnight skies,
Before time taught its bitter September.

Rewind the cassette of forgotten days,
When laughter came easy and tears dried fast,
When summer seemed endless, too golden to last,
Before we walked separate, diverging ways.

Remember the hands that once held you tight,
The voices now silent but echoing still,
The promises made on that distant hill,
Before darkness descended and dimmed the light.

In memory's theater we're both audience and cast,
Directors of scenes we cannot reshoot,
Each moment preserved like a withering fruit,
Sweet in recollection, forever surpassed.

Rewind life and remember—we're stories untold,
Collections of moments both bitter and bold.

The Reel of Memory

Rewind life and remember
the taste of rain on your tongue,
the symphony of crickets serenading dusk,
the weight of your mother's hand in yours.

Rewind life and remember
the first time your heart shattered,
how you gathered the fragments
and rebuilt something stronger, something new.

In the projector room of your mind,
shadows dance across the wall—
some scenes play in vivid color,
others fade to monochrome.

The film sometimes catches,
burns holes in precious frames,
or splices moments out of sequence,
creating beautiful impossible timelines.

Rewind life and remember
the person you were yesterday,
the child you once were,
the elder you will become.

All versions of you exist simultaneously,
a quantum entanglement of selves,
connected by the gossamer thread
of persistent consciousness.

MEMORY'S CAROUSEL

Rewind life and remember—
The carousel spins backward,
Wooden horses rising and falling
To the music box melody of yesterday.

I am five again, sticky-fingered,
Clutching cotton candy clouds,
My father's shadow tall beside me,
Before cancer ate him from within.

I am sixteen, trembling lips
Meeting another's for the first time,
The world exploding into color
Before heartbreak painted everything gray.

I am thirty, holding my newborn,
A universe cradled in uncertain arms,
Before I learned that love
Is terror and wonder intertwined.

Rewind life and remember—
Not to live in backward glances,
But to recognize how each moment
Becomes the foundation for the next.

The carousel never truly reverses;
It simply turns and turns and turns,
And we, the riders, carry our memories
Like precious tokens in our pockets.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'rewind life and remember'

responses.text:
Rewind Life and Remember

If I could pull time's thread backward,
Unravel the tapestry of years spent,
I'd pause at each golden moment—
The first kiss beneath autumn's canopy,
Laughter echoing across summer lakes,
Tears that baptized new beginnings.

Memories flicker like old film reels,
Jumping frames of joy and sorrow,
Blurring at edges where truth meets wish.
I'd smooth those corners with gentle fingers,
Holding each fragment to the light,
Seeing how they shaped this present self.

To rewind life is to remember
Not just what was, but what might have been—
Roads untaken, words unspoken,
Love unrequited or freely given.
In remembering, we live twice:
Once in the moment, once in reflection,
Each version teaching us how to be whole.

Cassette Memories

Press rewind on the cassette player of consciousness,
Watch as the spools turn counterclockwise,
Years spinning backward through the machine of mind.
Summer picnics reappear, sandwiches half-eaten,
Laughter preserved in amber afternoon light.

Rewind further—college hallways,
The scent of coffee and possibility,
Friendships formed in fluorescent-lit study rooms,
Hearts broken and mended on rain-slick sidewalks.

Childhood emerges: skinned knees and popsicle-stained lips,
The weight of a parent's hand around your smaller one,
Secrets whispered to stuffed animals in the dark.

To remember is to resurrect,
To breathe life into ghosts of ourselves.
We are time travelers in our own narratives,
Archaeologists of personal history,
Unearthing artifacts of who we once were,
To understand who we have become.

The Time Collector

I collect moments like seashells,
Some smooth from constant handling,
Others still jagged at the edges,
Cutting when I reach for them too quickly.

If I could rewind the cosmic film,
I'd pause at frames I rushed through:
The last conversation with my grandmother,
The way sunlight caught in your hair that Tuesday,
The ordinary breakfast before everything changed.

Memory is selective—a curator with bias—
Preserving what glitters or wounds deepest,
Discarding mundane Tuesdays and Thursdays
That might have held quiet revelations.

To remember is to recreate,
To paint with colors that may never have existed,
To compose music from fragments of sound.

Yet in this imperfect remembering,
We find ourselves—past and present intertwined,
A double helix of experience,
Writing our story backward and forward,
Until time itself unspools completely.

Palimpsest

Life layered upon itself—
A palimpsest of days and nights,
Each moment writing over the last,
Yet traces remain beneath the surface.

To rewind is to peel back these layers,
Revealing the ghost-writing of previous selves:
The child who feared thunderstorms,
The teenager who wrote poetry by moonlight,
The adult who learned to love silence.

Remembrance is archaeology of the self—
Digging through strata of experience,
Brushing dust from artifacts of joy and pain,
Cataloguing what should be preserved.

Some memories resist excavation,
Burying themselves deeper with each attempt,
While others emerge unbidden,
Sharp and clear as yesterday's sunrise.

In this rewinding and remembering,
We become both archaeologist and artifact,
The one who searches and the one who is found,
Eternal students of our own histories,
Translating the language of who we once were.

The Backward Glance

If time were a river, I'd swim upstream,
Against the current of passing days,
To visit islands of memory
Where younger versions of me still play.

Rewind the clock, unwind the spring,
Undo the knots that years have tied.
I'd whisper wisdom to my former self,
Watch understanding bloom in younger eyes.

But memory is no loyal historian—
It embellishes, erases, rearranges,
Collages fragments into beautiful lies
We tell ourselves to make sense of change.

Still, I remember:
The taste of rain on summer evenings,
The weight of books that changed my mind,
Hands that held mine through darkness,
Voices that shaped my understanding.

To rewind and remember is to acknowledge
That we are not one self but many,
A procession of beings through time,
Each one holding a piece of the puzzle
That forms this present, imperfect whole.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I was a grovelling creature once,'

responses.text:
I was a grovelling creature once,
Crawling through mud and shame,
My spine a wilted question mark,
My spirit crushed and tame.

I fed on scraps of others' praise,
And starved when none was found,
I made myself so very small,
Barely disturbing ground.

But something in me sparked alive,
A flame that would not die,
I stretched my limbs, unfurled my thoughts,
And dared to question why.

Now standing tall beneath the sun,
No longer bound to earth,
I recognize that grovelling thing
As cocoon before birth.

Though shadows of that creature stir
When doubt comes creeping in,
I need only remember how
To shed that former skin.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Bent low beneath the weight of stars,
My hands deep in the soil of shame,
Collecting wounds like mason jars.

The universe seemed built of boots
And I, designed for crushing—
A beetle scurrying between
The cracks of others' rushing.

How strange to find that dignity
Grows wild like stubborn weeds,
That even trampled gardens hold
The promise of their seeds.

Now vertical, I face the sky,
No longer eating dust,
The grovelling creature taught me this:
Survival is a must.

Sometimes I dream in horizontal,
Remembering the view—
How different the world appears
When looking up at you.

I was a grovelling creature once,
A shadow of a shadow's ghost,
Apologizing for the space
My meager form would boast.

I genuflected to the world,
Made altars of my fears,
And sacrificed my voice upon
The altar of their sneers.

But even worms will turn, they say,
And turn is what I did—
Unfolded from my crumpled state,
Tossed off the heavy lid.

The metamorphosis was slow,
Painful and incomplete,
Yet inch by inch, I claimed the air
Above me as my seat.

That grovelling creature lives in me,
A memory, a scar,
Reminding how the lowest depth
Reveals how high we are.

I was a grovelling creature once,
Belly pressed to cold stone floor,
Accepting crumbs of kindness like
A beggar at the door.

I learned the art of shrinking down,
Of making myself less,
A chameleon of compliance,
Camouflaged in stress.

What alchemy transformed me then?
What lightning struck my chains?
Perhaps it was the simple truth
That life outlasts our pains.

Or maybe it was rage that grew
Too large for me to hold—
The kind that melts submission down
And forges something bold.

I stand now at my full height, yes,
But honor still that form
That knew how to survive the drought
Until it met the storm.

I was a grovelling creature once,
My eyes fixed on the ground,
Collecting dust upon my knees,
Afraid to make a sound.

I measured out my worth in nods
And smiles from passers-by,
A mirror with no image save
What others would imply.

The revolution came so soft—
A whisper, not a shout—
A question forming in my mind:
What am I about?

The answer rose like mercury,
Urgent and silver-quick,
A poison to that former self,
A necessary sick.

I mourn sometimes that creature's death,
Its simple, certain ways—
But stand now in the complex light
Of undetermined days.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy when summer skies bloom,
Laughter like petals that scatter and fly.
Hands intertwined in the gathering gloom,
Whispering secrets as clouds drift by.

People are happy in moments so small,
A child's first steps on uncertain feet.
The scent of rain on a garden wall,
Strangers whose glances by chance may meet.

People are happy despite all the pain,
Carrying burdens with shoulders strong.
Dancing together through sunshine and rain,
Humming the notes of an ancient song.

People are happy when truth is revealed,
When masks are dropped and hearts laid bare.
In silent connection, souls are healed,
In the sacred knowledge that someone is there.

People are happy...
Or so the saying goes,
But happiness flows like water
Through cupped and leaking hands.

People are happy when the moon is full,
When bellies are warm with food,
When children sleep soundly
And debts are momentarily forgotten.

People are happy in the spaces between—
Between alarm clocks and deadlines,
Between news cycles and notifications,
In stolen breaths of quiet wonder.

People are happy despite themselves,
Despite the world's persistent shadows,
Despite the knowledge of impermanence
That haunts our brightest days.

People are happy...
Not as a constant state,
But as lightning flashes in darkness—
Brief, brilliant, and worth everything.

People are happy when the morning breaks
And dew glistens like scattered diamonds.
They smile at the promise each sunrise makes,
While birds compose their joyful hymns.

People are happy sharing humble meals,
Bread broken between cherished friends.
It's in such moments the spirit feels
A wealth no fortune comprehends.

People are happy crafting with their hands,
Creating beauty from mere thought.
Building bridges across divided lands,
Teaching lessons time has taught.

People are happy in the arms of love,
Sheltered from life's raging storm.
Drawing strength from stars that shine above,
Keeping hearts and hopes still warm.

People are happy not in things they own,
But in the lives that they touch.
In seeds of kindness they have sown,
Little acts that matter much.

People are happy when they forget to be sad,
When the weight of existence briefly lifts.
Like autumn leaves dancing in mad
Celebration before winter's drift.

People are happy in contradictions—
In tearful reunions and bittersweet ends,
In the chaos of their own convictions,
In the breaking of what never bends.

People are happy without knowing why,
A chemical surge, a neurological trick.
A sunset painting the evening sky,
A heartbeat's rhythm, steady and quick.

People are happy in collective delusion,
Ignoring the truth that happiness fades.
Finding comfort in the illusion
That joy outlasts all darkening shades.

People are happy... or perhaps just alive,
Clinging to moments that feel like flight.
Struggling, laughing, trying to survive,
Flickering candles against infinite night.

People are happy gathering shells by the shore,
Feet sinking in sand as waves kiss the land.
Collecting memories, wanting nothing more
Than this moment held in the palm of a hand.

People are happy sharing stories at night,
Voices soft around the campfire's glow.
Faces illuminated in dancing light,
Belonging to somewhere, to someone they know.

People are happy tending gardens with care,
Witnessing life emerge from darkened soil.
Breathing deeply the fragrant summer air,
Finding purpose in honest, earthly toil.

People are happy when eyes truly meet,
When guards fall away like autumn leaves.
In genuine connection, rare and sweet,
A tapestry of trust the heart weaves.

People are happy not in grand design,
But in ordinary magic, simply being.
In the sacred space where stars align,
And for one brief moment, they are seeing.

People are happy when they forget to count
The minutes, the dollars, the calories, the cost.
When time becomes water and they're learning to float,
No longer afraid of getting lost.

People are happy in gardens they've grown,
From seeds of kindness planted years before.
In harvests of friendship, in love they have shown,
In giving when they could have given more.

People are happy with bare feet in grass,
With hands intertwined under starry skies.
In moments that linger, in moments that pass,
In truth that outshines the prettiest lies.

People are happy when they finally see
That joy isn't something we chase or we buy.
It's breathing and being and choosing to be
Present for each second that flutters by.

People are happy when the world's asleep,
And city lights flicker like fallen stars.
Secrets whispered, promises to keep,
Midnight confessions in parked cars.

People are happy in the chaos of life,
In crowded kitchens and noisy halls.
Cutting through tension with a butter knife,
Laughter echoing off the walls.

People are happy in their solitude,
With books that transport to distant lands.
A quiet strength, a certain fortitude,
The universe held in their hands.

People are happy despite endless rain,
Despite heartache and unbearable loss.
Finding reasons to smile through the pain,
Bearing unimaginable cost.

People are happy—what a curious thing,
This resilience we cannot explain.
How the human heart continues to sing,
Even when nothing remains.

People are happy when they stop to watch
The sunset paint the sky in gold and red,
When they release the things they cannot catch,
And cherish what they have instead.

People are happy in their imperfection,
In wrinkles earned through years of hearty laughs,
In mirrors that show more than just reflection,
In journeys marked by crooked paths.

People are happy building bridges, not walls,
Connecting hearts across impossible divides,
Rising stronger after every fall,
Discovering what truly resides inside.

People are happy learning how to dance
With grief and joy as equal partners here,
Embracing every risk and every chance,
Finding courage in the face of fear.

People are happy not because life's easy,
But because they've learned the sacred art
Of finding beauty in what's wild and messy—
The glorious beating of the human heart.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:

People are happy with memories made,

People are happy in photographs posed,

People are happy when no one's around,

People are happy when dancing in rain,

They're happy with ice cream that drips down their chin,
And the sound of the ocean waves rolling in.

People are happy with firefly nights,

They're happy with inside jokes only they know,
And the first perfect crunch through fresh-fallen snow.

People are happy with songs they can't sing,
But belt out regardless of what others think.
They're happy with letters received in the mail,

People are happy—it's simple and true—
When they stop seeking happiness as something to do
And realize instead it was there all along,

People are happy when systems collapse,

People are happy in quantum delight,

People are happy when mind becomes still,

People are happy beyond space and time,

People are happy in villages small,

People are happy with soil in their hands,

They find joy in belonging, in knowing their part,
In the intricate web that sustains every heart.

People are happy with cycles of time,
With seasons that shift in a rhythm sublime.
They celebrate births and they honor the dead,

People are happy when wisdom grows deep,
When elders are treasured and memories keep.
For happiness flows not from wealth or from fame,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:
People are happy when the sun breaks through

People are happy in the smallest things—
A child's laughter, a stranger's smile,

People are happy in connection's grace,

Yet happiness is fleeting, quick to fade,

People are happy... if only for a while.

Enough to make the hardest journey worthwhile,
Enough to keep us knocking at joy's doors.

People are happy
when no one is watching,
when shoes come off
and socks slide on hardwood floors.

People are happy
in supermarket aisles,
finding the last ripe avocado,
a small victory against the day.

People are happy
in the spaces between words,
in text messages that arrive
when hope had almost vanished.

People are happy
beneath heavy blankets
as thunder cracks the sky,
safe in temporary shelters.

People are happy
with dirt under fingernails,
growing things that feed,
that bloom, that remember.

People are happy
when returning home,
whatever home means—
a person, a place, a feeling.

People are happy
in fleeting moments,
collecting them like shells,
pockets heavy with joy.

People are happy, or so they claim to be,
With plastered smiles and rehearsed laughs,
Posting curated moments for all to see,
While hiding tears in photographs.

People are happy when they compare
Their fortunes to those who have less.
A dangerous game of despair,
Building joy on others' distress.

People are happy in ignorant bliss,
Avoiding news that might disturb.
The comfortable bubble they dismiss
Truths too painful to disturb.

People are happy in collective lies,
In shared delusions we maintain.
The myths of progress, the compromise
Of conscience for material gain.

Yet people are happy in resistance too,
In small rebellions against despair.
In finding purpose, in staying true
To the better world they dare to share.

People are happy... a complicated state,
Neither permanent nor pure.
A fragile choice we navigate
In a world so hard to endure.

People are happy when morning dew
Clings to spider webs like crystal beads,
When coffee steam curls into view,
And the day holds more than what one needs.

People are happy in gardens grown,
From seeds of patience, time, and care.
In harvesting what they have sown,
In breathing deep the fragrant air.

People are happy beside the sea,
Where waves erase footprints in sand.
In that vast blue infinity,
They find perspective, understand.

People are happy around a fire,
Faces glowing with ancient light.
Stories shared that never tire,
Keeping close against the night.

People are happy creating art,
Transforming pain to something new.
Healing wounds that tore apart,
By making beauty strange and true.

People are happy loving well,
Not perfect love, but honest, kind.
In that brave space where truth can dwell,
Where souls connect and intertwine.

People are happy until they're not,
Swinging pendulums of joy and grief.
One moment caught in pleasure's plot,
The next in sorrow beyond belief.

People are happy in measured doses,
Carefully rationed throughout their days.
Between the thorns, they seek the roses,
Navigating life's complex maze.

People are happy despite the news,
Despite the warnings, despite the signs.
A stubborn hope they refuse to lose,
Even as the world declines.

People are happy in memories kept,
In photographs yellowed with time.
In promises made and sometimes kept,
In ordinary moments sublime.

People are happy in rebellion's spark,
In standing firm against the tide.
In finding light within the dark,
In choosing love over foolish pride.

People are happy... or at least they try,
And perhaps that trying is enough—
To seek joy under an uncertain sky,
To believe in love when times are rough.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'People are happy...'

responses.text:

People are happy, or so they pretend,

People are happy when they cease to chase

People are happy gathered 'round the flame

To keep each other safe, and fed, and warm.

People are happy digging in the soil,

People are happy when they finally know

People are happy, so the saying goes,

People are happy in collective voice,

People are happy in the wild, untamed,

responses.text:

People are happy not in the having,

People are happy when rain falls on parched earth,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:
It seems like Light Years ago
When stars were our only guide,
When promises were etched in constellations
And your hand fit perfectly in mine.

Galaxies have formed and faded
In the space between then and now,
Each memory a distant planet
Orbiting what we once allowed.

I measure time in cosmic distances,
In the slow decay of burning suns.
What once felt close enough to touch
Now stretches beyond where light can run.

It seems like Light Years ago
That we danced under silver moons,
Now I stand alone in the darkness
Wondering if you remember too soon.

Perhaps in some parallel universe
We're still caught in that moment's glow,
Frozen in time like ancient starlight
From a place I used to know.

It seems like Light Years ago
When childhood wrapped me in wonder,
When summer days stretched eternal
And time couldn't tear us asunder.

The backyard was our universe,
Tree forts our cosmic stations,
Bicycle trails mapped constellations
Across neighborhood formations.

It seems like Light Years ago
Yet somehow just yesterday,
When scraped knees were our battle scars
And monsters kept at bay.

Now calendars mark the distance
Between who I was and am,
Each rotation around the sun
A light year in this lifespan.

How strange that memories travel
Faster than light ever could,
Transporting me across decades
To that place where innocence stood.

It seems like Light Years ago
That we inhabited the same space,
Your atoms dancing with mine
In that small infinity we embraced.

Quantum entanglement, they say,
Means particles once joined stay connected.
Perhaps that explains why I feel you still
Though galaxies keep us redirected.

It seems like Light Years ago
That your voice created gravity,
Anchoring me to the present moment
Before time stretched to depravity.

I calculate the distance now
In birthdays, seasons, tears,
In the slow erosion of photographs
And the accumulation of fears.

Yet somehow across this cosmic void
I sense you're gazing at the same stars,
Remembering when our universe
Wasn't measured in these scars.

It seems like Light Years ago
When our nation stood united,
Before the fractures and divisions
Left our collective soul benighted.

The shared dreams that once propelled us
Now drift like cosmic debris,
Scattered across political space
Where common ground used to be.

It seems like Light Years ago
When we listened more than spoke,
When compromise wasn't weakness
And empathy hadn't broke.

I search the horizon for signals
Of that civilization we built,
Like an astronomer scanning for life
On planets abandoned to guilt.

Perhaps if we measure the distance
Not in blame but in shared pain,
We might find that journey homeward
And become one world again.

It seems like Light Years ago
I held certainty in my hands,
Confident in paths forward
Before life rewrote its plans.

Now I navigate by different stars,
Constellation maps redrawn,
The universe expanding faster
Than my understanding dawn.

It seems like Light Years ago
I knew exactly who I'd be,
Before experience bent light around
The gravity of reality.

Each decision a pulsar blinking,
Each choice a nebula birth,
Creating this strange astronomy
Of who I've become on Earth.

Yet in this vast cosmic journey
Where nothing remains the same,
I find beauty in the distance traveled
And peace in speaking my name.

Still burning
Preserved in light that travels endlessly
Toward an observer who might understand
What we were.

It seems like Light Years ago
That we planted seeds of possibility
In soil made rich with hope and youth,
Not knowing what strange fruit would bloom.

Quasars pulsed between decisions,
Supermassive moments collapsed and expanded,
As we navigated cosmic crossroads,
Never certain which path led home.

How strange to think those distant selves
Still travel through space, light undiminished,
Theoretically visible through powerful enough lenses—
Ghosts performing the same acts eternally.

Scientists say nothing moves faster than light,
Yet memory outpaces it easily,
Flashing backward through decades
In the milliseconds between heartbeats.

It seems like Light Years ago
Yet paradoxically present,
A quantum entanglement of then and now,
Where observation changes everything,
And nothing changes at all—
This universe where we remain
Both impossibly distant
And inescapably here.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It seems like Light Years ago'

responses.text:

It seems like Light Years ago—

I remember your voice—a pulsar,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I had eight birds hatched in one nest,'

responses.text:
Eight Birds of Wonder

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
Each feathered soul uniquely blessed.
One with eyes like midnight stars,
One with wings that reached too far.

Third sang songs of ancient lore,
Fourth was silent, evermore.
Fifth had plumage gold and bright,
Sixth preferred the cloak of night.

Seventh bird was quick to fly,
Eighth content to wonder why.
Together formed a symphony,
Of different hearts in harmony.

Each morning brought their varied calls,
Each twilight, different shadows fall.
I watched them grow, then watched them leave,
One by one, my heart would grieve.

Yet in their flight, I came to know,
That love means learning to let go.
Eight birds hatched in one small nest,
Eight paths diverging, east to west.

Nestlings

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
A cacophony of beaks and down,
Hungry mouths stretched skyward,
Eyes still sealed against the dawn.

Each morning brought the frantic rush,
Of gathering worms and seeds and flies,
My wings worn thin from endless trips,
Beneath unforgiving summer skies.

They grew so fast, those little ones,
From naked things to feathered dreams,
Their individual songs emerging,
Like separate notes in nature's schemes.

One by one they tested wings,
Teetering on the nest's rough edge,
Then leaping into empty air,
A brave fulfillment of ancient pledge.

Now my nest sits hollow, quiet,
The branches empty where they perched,
But sometimes when the wind blows right,
I hear their songs across the earth.

Octet

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
A miracle of life eight times blessed.
First came Dawn with golden crest,
Then Noon whose song outshone the rest.

Storm arrived with thunder-wings,
While Echo mimicked all she sings.
Dusk wore feathers inky-blue,
And Whisper's voice was soft as dew.

Midnight hatched when stars appeared,
His eyes reflecting all they peered.
Lastly came my sweet Silence,
Whose wordless wisdom proved immense.

Eight beaks to feed, eight songs to learn,
Eight paths to watch with deep concern.
Eight different flights into the sky,
Eight reasons both to smile and cry.

They scattered like the wind's own seeds,
Each following where their nature leads.
Yet in my heart they still remain,
Eight birds who will return again.

Brood

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
Fragile bodies pressed against my breast.
Each morning's hunger woke me first,
Each evening's quiet quenched my thirst.

The smallest one had broken wings,
The strongest one could almost sing.
The third one watched with cautious eyes,
The fourth one yearned for distant skies.

My fifth child wore the brightest coat,
My sixth possessed the clearest note.
The seventh seemed to understand
The language of the starry band.

My eighth, my last, my quietest one,
Would gaze for hours at the sun.
I taught them all to hunt and fly,
To read the weather in the sky.

One autumn day they all took flight,
Eight separate journeys through the light.
I watch the empty nest and know
That this is how all children grow.

The Octave

I had eight birds hatched in one nest,
A clutch of possibilities unguessed.
Eight beating hearts beneath my wing,
Eight different songs they'd learn to sing.

The first one flew before the rest,
Impatient soul who couldn't rest.
The second stayed till winter came,
Content to watch the world through rain.

My third and fourth fought constantly,
Yet missed each other terribly
When fifth one's illness drew my care,
And sixth one's silence filled the air.

The seventh had the strangest eyes,
That seemed to peer through my disguise.
The eighth, the runt, grew strongest still,
With stubborn heart and iron will.

Now scattered across continents,
They send their songs like monuments
To that small nest where life began,
Eight birds, one mother, nature's plan.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
Winter's Blanket

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Silent crystals from heavens descend,
Transforming landscapes once familiar,
Into wonderlands that have no end.

Dreams wrapped in white, suspended moments,
Time slows beneath the weighted boughs,
Footprints vanish with each new flurry,
As nature fulfills its ancient vows.

Children's laughter pierces still air,
Their joy unmarred by winter's chill,
While elders watch through frosted windows,
Remembering when they, too, felt that thrill.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Cleansing earth with its pure embrace,
Reminding us in gentle whispers,
Of beauty found in slowing pace.

Endless White

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Endless white upon the ground.
Voices hushed by nature's cover,
Not a single stirring sound.

Flakes descending, ever gentle,
Dancing down from skies of gray.
Time suspended, fundamental,
As the hours drift away.

Memories frozen like the landscape,
Thoughts preserved in crystal form.
Sorrow buried, joy unearthed,
In this peaceful, swirling storm.

Cities, forests, mountains, valleys,
All united in pristine dress.
Equal now beneath the pallid
Weight of winter's soft caress.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Binding us in shared reprieve.
Universal white surrender,
Teaching us, at last, to breathe.

The Great Equalizer

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Erasing boundaries drawn by man.
No rich, no poor, no king, no pauper,
Just white upon the frozen land.

The skyscrapers and humble hovels,
Wear the same crystalline crown.
As flakes descend in silent travels,
Transforming every field and town.

What magic in this cold communion,
That teaches us equality?
A temporary pale reunion,
Of earth in white serenity.

The children of all nations playing,
In drifts that know no flag or creed.
While adults pause, their conflicts staying,
To witness beauty guaranteed.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A message sent from skies above.
That underneath our different covers,
We share one home, one life, one love.

Whispers of Ice

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Like secrets falling from the sky.
Ancient whispers none discover,
Tales of eons passing by.

Crystals formed in clouds' dark chambers,
Unique patterns, billions strong.
Nature's art that never labors,
Yet creates what we find wrong.

Ghostly silence fills the spaces,
Where once chaos reigned supreme.
Muffled now are human traces,
As if life were but a dream.

In this white and weightless prison,
Time stands frozen, caught between.
Moments lost and visions risen,

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,

Winter's mantle, earth's last lover,

The Universal Blanket

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
From mountain peaks to desert plains.
A transformation none could hover,
Above, beyond, or in between.

The busy streets of Tokyo silenced,
Sahara dunes dressed all in white.
Amazon jungles, strangely compliant,
Surrendered to the snowflakes' might.

Penguins in Antarctica bewildered,
By depths increasing day by day.
While children in Manila filtered,
Through unfamiliar frozen play.

A universal reset button,
Pressed by forces we can't control.
Earth wrapped in white, problems forgotten,
A chance to cleanse both land and soul.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Uniting us in shared surprise.
Teaching lessons we must discover:
In nature's hands, our future lies.

The Great Equalization

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'It snowed and snowed ,the whole world over,'

responses.text:
The Blanketed Earth

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Silent crystals claiming each uncovered space.
Time suspended in white-feathered hover,
As earth donned its purest lace.

From mountain peaks to valley floors,
The snow erased all borders drawn by man.
It settled gently upon warring shores,
Uniting lands in winter's peaceful plan.

Children's laughter echoed through the hush,
Their footprints marking temporary art.
As twilight painted skies in lavender blush,
The world grew quiet, still as a sleeping heart.

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
A momentary truce in nature's silent power.
Where we stood as humble witness-lover,
To the earth transformed within the hour.

Endless White

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Like memories falling from heaven's mind.
Each flake a forgotten whisper, a wandering lover,
Tracing patterns no human designed.

The cities drowned in quiet submission,
Skyscrapers wrapped in ghostly shrouds.
Streets emptied of their noisy ambition,
As snow kept falling from pregnant clouds.

I watched from my window, breath creating fog,
As the familiar transformed to foreign land.
The neighbor's fence, the sleeping dog,
All rendered new by nature's hand.

Perhaps this is how endings begin—
In beautiful silence, in cleansing white.
It snowed and snowed, erasing sin,
Offering the world a chance to rewrite.

Winter's Dominion

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Relentless in its cold embrace.
Winter's breath, a restless rover,
Redefining every familiar place.

Pine trees bowed beneath crystal weight,
Animals huddled in burrows deep.
The clock of seasons told us to wait,
As the earth fell into dreamless sleep.

Houses became islands in white seas,
Smoke from chimneys the only sign
That beneath this frozen expertise,
Life continued its stubborn design.

How small we are against such might,
How fragile our constructed ways.
It snowed and snowed through day and night,
Reminding us of borrowed days.

Yet in this white imprisonment,
I found a strange and welcome peace—
As if the snow, heaven-sent,
Granted the world a brief release.

The Great Equalizer

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
Democratic in its distribution, blind to worth.
No preference for palace or for hovel,
The same white blanket for the entire earth.

The rich man's garden and the poor man's path,
Both disappeared beneath the drifting white.
Nature's justice, not driven by wrath,
But by the simple balance of what's right.

The tracks of wolves merged with those of deer,
All creatures leaving signatures in snow.
The boundary between far and near
Blurred in the landscape's ethereal glow.

We stood as equals under falling flakes,
Our differences rendered obsolete.
It snowed and snowed, until it makes
A world where all divisions obsolete.

Perhaps in this we find a truth to hold—
That underneath our artificial lines,
We share one earth, one story to be told,
Connected by what nature's hand designs.

Frozen Whispers

It snowed and snowed, the whole world over,
As if the stars had shed their silver skin.
Each crystalline tear, a cosmic rover,
Transforming chaos to discipline.

The noisy world grew muffled, hushed,
Sounds absorbed by cotton-candy air.
Even time seemed somewhat crushed,
Slowed by winter's solemn prayer.

I ventured out when darkness fell,
To stand alone in nature's silent hall.
No church or temple cast such spell,
As this cathedral, white and tall.

My breath, a ghost against the night,
Joined ancient spirits in their dance.
It snowed and snowed with quiet might,
Holding earth in frozen trance.

Tomorrow, footprints will appear,
Life resuming its relentless pace.
But tonight, the message clear:
Beauty needs only stillness, time and space.

responses.text:

The Great Equalizer

Winter's Veil

Universal Blanket

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Mirrors of a sky turning gray,
Where once rivers rushed with might,
Now silent basins catch the light.

I trace my fingers through the mud,
Remembering when water stood
High enough to swallow trees,
Before the long drought brought us to our knees.

Small fish circle in desperate arcs,
Their silver bodies leaving marks
Upon the surface tension thin,
As if to map the world they're in.

The earth has cracked its thirsty lips,
As time through narrow hourglass slips.
These pools, like memories, will fade,
Leaving only ghosts of what was made.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
The last tears of a land in pain.

DWINDLING POOLS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where once an ocean roared.
I cup my hands around what's left,
these precious liquid hoards.

The sun beats down with ruthless glare
upon the parched terrain.
Each ripple counts as currency
in nature's stark domain.

Within these shallow sanctuaries
tadpoles race against time,
their fragile bodies testament
to change's brutal climb.

I watch as creatures gather close,
all enemies now friends,
the heron stands beside the fox—
survival makes amends.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
like memories we clutch,
diminishing with every day,
we've always asked too much.

Perhaps in this reflection clear
of what we've left behind,
we'll finally see our folly here
before we go completely blind.

REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where children once splashed with abandon
Their laughter evaporated like the waters
Leaving only hollows in the earth.

I walk the riverbed, now cracked and dry,
My footprints joining ancient fossils
As if I too am becoming history,
A relic of when abundance flowed.

The herons have abandoned their stations,
Their long-legged patience unrewarded.
Only the most stubborn creatures linger,
Gathered at these final shrinking altars.

I kneel beside one murky offering,
Watch my reflection fragment and reform.
In these waters, I see tomorrow's thirst,
And yesterday's careless consumption.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Not enough to quench what's coming,
Not enough to wash away our sins,
Just enough to show us what we've done.

LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Like scattered thoughts across a barren mind,
Each one holding fragments of what was—
Tiny universes, isolated, undefined.

In their depths swim memories of flood,
Of times when water knew no boundary or shore.
Now contained in depressions of the land,
They wait for rains that come no more.

I've watched them shrink through seasons long,
Their edges creeping slowly toward their heart.
The wildlife gathers denser by the day,
A congregation knowing they'll soon part.

These pools hold secrets in their muddy beds—
Ancient whispers, promises, and lies.
They've seen civilizations rise and fall
Reflected in their ever-changing eyes.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
As twilight paints their surface gold and red.
I sit beside them as they disappear,
Watching futures evaporate instead.

AFTER THE DELUGE

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once vast waters surged and swelled.
The flood has fled, leaving behind
Small liquid jewels in pockets held.

I count them like a miser's coins—
One here beneath the willow's shade,
Another nestled in the rocks,
A third where deer have paths remade.

Each holds a universe complete:
Mosquito larvae, water striders,
Tiny fish with nowhere to go,
Last survivors, final abiders.

The mud around their edges dries
In patterns like a prophet's script,
Concentric rings of history
From which the future might be stripped.

I wonder as I wander here
Between these islands soon to fade,
If we are also dwindling pools—
Brief moments where life's waters stayed.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I guard their shimmer while I can,
Knowing tomorrow's thirsty sun
Will finish what the drought began.

Drought Dreams

Extinction's Edge

We stand at the edge of the deepest pool,

Sacred Waters

Feeling the cool resistance of what endures.

OASIS FADING

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once an oasis flourished green,
The desert's golden fingers now extend
Across what water had kept clean.

The palms stand sentinel, remembering
How their roots once drank their fill,
Now they guard these precious mirrors
Shrinking smaller, smaller still.

Caravans no longer stop here—
The word has spread across the dunes
Of how this sanctuary is surrendering
To the heat of countless noons.

I trace the former shoreline,
A ghost boundary etched in sand,
And listen for the echoes
Of abundance in this land.

The camels sense the change as well,
Their ancient instincts understand
The fragile balance shifting
As water relinquishes to land.

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Holding stars within their face—
The universe reflected
In each disappearing place.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a mighty river flowed,
Their shrinking borders marked with stain
Of what the earth once proudly showed.

The sun beats down with ruthless glare
On memories of abundance past,
Cracked mud like skin too parched to bear
The weight of changes coming fast.

Small creatures gather at the edge,
Their futures balanced on the brink.
A silent, desperate privilege
To find somewhere to drink.

I too have felt my spirit drain,
Leaving hollows where floods once surged.
Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where hopes and dreams were once submerged.

Yet in these pools, though small they be,
Life concentrates its fierce desire.
Perhaps in loss we truly see
What depths within us still inspire.

DESERT MEMORY

Just a few dwindling pools remain
like teardrops on the desert's face,
each one a liquid memory
of when abundance had its place.

The canyon walls remember floods,
their shoulders carved by rushing strength.
Now silence echoes through the dust
where water once proclaimed its length.

A tortoise inches to the brink
of murky sanctuary's edge,
its ancient wisdom knows too well
the value of this liquid pledge.

The evening light transforms each pool
to burnished gold against the stone.
What's temporary now seems rare,
a treasure time has briefly loaned.

I dip my fingers in the cool
and feel millennia pass through skin.
Just a few dwindling pools remain—
where endings end and worlds begin.

REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where oceans of ourselves once were;
Shimmering mirrors that contain
The fragments of what we prefer
To remember—moments crystallized
In depths that slowly disappear.

I walk the basin of my past,
Footprints filling with brackish tears.
These puddles weren't meant to last—
Each one evaporates and clears
Space for the desert that waits beneath
Patient as only time can be.

I cup my hands around the last
Reflection of who I used to be.
The water slips between my grasp,
Reluctant to remain with me.
The sun continues its slow burn,
Indifferent to what I might learn.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I drink from them while I still can,
Tasting the salt of joy and pain,
Before the final grains of sand
Reclaim the landscape of my heart
And teach me how to start again.

FINAL WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once a lake spread wide and deep.
The earth has swallowed back its gift,
A promise it could never keep.

The herons no longer wade these shores,
Their long-legged shadows fled with rain.
The fish have vanished with the depths,
Leaving only loss and pain.

I kneel beside the muddy brink
Where water clings to life by threads,
Reflecting clouds that will not drink
Their fill until the season spreads
Its mercy back upon this land.

My cupped hands lift what little stays,
A mirror growing ever small.
I see myself in its glazed eye—
How we persist despite it all,
How we collect in hollows when
The world turns harsh and resources thin.

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Of who we were before the drought.
Yet in their shrinking, we contain
More truth than when waters stretched out.

PERSISTENCE

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Caught in the hollows of stone,
Like memories trapped in a fading brain,
Refusing to leave us alone.

The creek bed stretches, parched and bare,
A skeleton picked by the sun.
Yet life still gathers, will not despair,
Where water's work is not done.

Dragonflies hover on gossamer wings,
Their shadows dance on the deep.
A thirsty fox at twilight drinks,
From treasures the earth still keeps.

I've wandered far through barren years,
Through landscapes scorched by pain,
To find that grace, like water, appears
In places that still sustain.

So cup your hands around what lasts,
When rivers of plenty run dry.
The future lives in the pooling past,
Reflecting an endless sky.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Enough for those who can see
That in scarcity's blessing we might attain
What abundance failed to free.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
REMNANTS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
mirrors of a sky indifferent to thirst.
The earth cracks like ancient pottery,
its patterns telling stories of abundance lost.

Where children once splashed and laughed,
now cautious birds tread lightly,
dipping beaks with reverent precision
as if drinking from the last holy chalice.

I trace the shoreline's retreat with my finger,
a map of our collective negligence.
Each puddle shrinks beneath the sun's gaze,
holding memories of rivers and streams.

In these shallow basins, life concentrates—
tadpoles racing against evaporation,
insects skating across tense surfaces,
all participants in this final ceremony.

Soon even these will vanish into dust,
leaving only the impression of water,
a ghost of moisture in the hollow ground,
and our parched souls wondering what we've done.

DROUGHT SONGS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
like scattered thoughts in a tired mind.
The land remembers when it swam
in abundance, when every depression
cradle-rocked the rain.

Now these isolated mirrors reflect
nothing but clouds that promise
and never deliver. Fish dreams
curl inward, scales tightening
against the inevitable dry.

I come here each morning to witness
the slow subtraction of water,
measuring yesterday against today,
watching dragonflies hover over
their shrinking kingdom.

The mud at the edges hardens,
cracks into geometric certainties,
while algae concentrates into green
intensities, making one last stand
against the relentless sun.

We who have taken too much
stand witness to this diminishment,
our throats as dry as prophecies
that went unheeded, our hands empty
of everything but regret.

LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where once a mighty river carved its will.
I kneel beside these orphaned waters,
fingerprints of a vanished giant,
and contemplate their lonely vigil.

Each pool holds a universe in miniature—
water skaters drawing silver equations,
beetles navigating through reed forests,
the occasional flash of a desperate fin
seeking deeper sanctuary.

The sun, once friend, now executioner,
draws the moisture into sky banks
that drift away to quench other thirsts.
I watch the waterline recede hourly,
time measured in centimeters of loss.

What prayers might preserve these last oases?
What sacrifice might appease the dry gods?
I leave footprints in the cracked mud,
each step an apology to what was flowing,
each shadow a promise I cannot keep.

Tomorrow, perhaps dust alone will mark
where these final pools once held their breath.

WATER MEMORY

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
like tears forgotten on a weathered cheek.
I walk the riverbed now—strange highway
where fish once dreamed in cool currents
and stones sang underwater symphonies.

The exposed pebbles, smooth as worry beads,
rattle beneath my feet, speaking in tongues
of drought and patience. They've seen this before,
they whisper, in cycles longer than our remembering,
though never hastened by human hands.

In these scattered pools, life compresses—
concentric rings of desperation tightening,
as minnows dart through increasingly crowded quarters
and herons stand sentinel, yellow eyes calculating
the mathematics of survival.

I dip my hand in one clear pool, feel its coolness
like a memory of abundance. The water trembles
at my touch, uncertain whether I come as friend
or final thief. I withdraw, leaving only my reflection,
a wavering promise to return when the rains do.

The sky holds its breath. The earth waits.
Just a few dwindling pools remain.

EVAPORATION

Just a few dwindling pools remain
where once a lake sprawled generous and wide.
I count them like the last coins of a fortune,
each one smaller than yesterday's accounting,
each one precious beyond measure.

The water striders seem confused,
their universe contracting without explanation.
Fish crowd in silvery panic, their backs
breaking the surface like questions
no one bothered to answer.

At night, animals gather in uneasy truces,
predator and prey sharing the same disappearing cup,
their reflections trembling together under stars
that seem suddenly too numerous, too bright,
too indifferent to our earthly thirst.

I remember swimming here as a child,
the cool depth swallowing my summer heat,
water so plentiful we splashed it at each other,
laughing as if abundance was our birthright,
as if some things could never be lost.

Now I photograph these final pools,
documenting the stages of farewell,
the earth's slow surrender to sky,
and wonder what new wisdom grows
in the hard soil of absence.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Just a few dwindling pools remain'

responses.text:
Just a few dwindling pools remain,

Perhaps the rains will come again,
To heal this scarred and thirsting plain.
Until that day, these pools remain,
The last oasis in the chain.

DWINDLING WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where once an ocean kissed the shore.
The memory of abundance fades
With each retreating tide that roars.

I cup my hands to hold what's left,
These precious drops of you and me.
The happiness we once possessed
Now shallow as a summer sea.

Time is the sun that steals away
The depths in which our love once swam.
Leaving exposed the rocky bed
Where creatures gasp for what they can.

I walk the basin of our past,
Collecting shells of what we said.
Each promise dried upon the sand,
Each vow now hollow as the dead.

Just a few dwindling pools remain.
I guard them with a jealous eye.
Knowing that when they too have gone,
A desert heart will testify.

ECHOES OF WATER

Just a few dwindling pools remain
Where children's laughter once cascaded free,
Their ripples catching sunlight's golden chain,
A testament to what used to be.

The forest floor, now carpeted in brown,
Holds moisture like a memory beneath,
While fungi kingdoms quietly crown
The fallen logs with spectral wreath.

The deer approach with cautious, gentle steps,
Their reflections trembling in murky glass.
They drink the earth's remaining depths,
As shadows lengthen through the grass.

Somewhere beneath, the aquifer still flows,
A hidden river coursing deep and slow.
It holds the promise winter always knows—
That spring will come and make these waters grow.

So in these pools, diminished though they are,
I see not just the drought that steals our peace,
But cycles turning near and far,
The endless dance that never seems to cease.

THE LAST WATERS

Just a few dwindling pools remain,
Like memories in an aging mind.
Fragmented, scattered, growing faint—
The water's whispers left behind.

Once mighty currents carved these stones,

Now silence settles in the bones
Of what was once a raging course.

Small creatures gather at the edge,
A democracy of thirst convenes.
Predator and prey share common pledge:
Survival in these final scenes.

The mud cracks form a cryptic text,
A language written by the drought.
Telling stories of what comes next
When even hope is running out.

I place my palm against the earth
And feel its fever burning through.
This planet in its time of dearth,
Demanding what we must now do.

Just a few dwindling pools remain—
Our last chance flowing through our hands.

DESERT MEDITATION

Just a few dwindling pools remain
In the hollows of ancient stone.
I sit beside their silver sheen
And find I'm not alone.

The desert breathes around me now,
Its patience spanning endless time.
Teaching that loss is not an end
But part of nature's rhyme.

These waters, though diminished, hold
The sky's reflection, clouds adrift.
In scarcity I've come to see
The value of this gift.

A lizard darts across the rock,

Then vanishes from sight.

The water's edge is ringed with salt,

Marking where abundance once extended,
Where life had always been.

I touch the surface with my hand,
Disturbing stillness with my need.
And understand how easily
Our presence makes worlds bleed.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:

When I am happy,

The world's sharp edges soften
Into curves I can navigate with ease.

I am both more and less myself—

To my essential nature, finally free
From the heavy armor I wear in sorrow.
