Branches reaching toward tomorrow's sky.

When I am happy,
The clock surrenders its tyranny.
Minutes transform to honey on my tongue,
Sweet and lingering, refusing to dissolve.

When I am happy,
I recognize strangers as mirrors,
Reflecting fragments of my own journey
In the creases of their smiling eyes.

When I am happy,
Music lives in my fingertips,
Words flow like rivers after rain,
And even silence holds melody.

When I am happy,
I understand that this too shall pass,
Yet paradoxically, this knowledge
Makes the happiness more complete.

When I am happy,
The world wears different clothes—
A coat of wonder, shoes of possibility,
A hat tilted toward adventure.

When I am happy,
My body becomes a lighthouse,
Illuminating dark corners
I once feared to explore.

When I am happy,
Memories reshape themselves,
Pain transforms to wisdom,
Regrets become necessary chapters.

When I am happy,
I speak in tongues of gratitude,
My words carrying weight of feathers,
Landing softly on listening ears.

When I am happy,
I recognize this truth:
Joy is not the absence of sorrow
But their dance together,
A balanced choreography
Of what it means to be alive.

When I am happy,
I collect dewdrops from spider webs,

To water drought-days yet to come.

When I am happy,
Gravity loosens its jealous grip.
My bones remember ancient wings,
My blood sings with forgotten flight.

When I am happy,
I speak the language of oak trees,
Understand the philosophy of rivers,
Translate the whispers of falling leaves.

When I am happy,
Time becomes circular rather than linear,
A wheel rather than an arrow,

When I am happy,
I finally understand—
This feeling was never elsewhere,
But waiting patiently within me all along.

When I am happy,
My heart beats in iambic pentameter,
A Shakespeare sonnet
Pumping through my veins.

When I am happy,
I notice things I've seen
A thousand times before:
The perfect spiral of a snail's shell,
The impossible mathematics of a spider's web,
The patient wisdom in my dog's eyes.

When I am happy,
I become a time traveler,
Visiting my past selves to whisper:
"This feeling will come again.
Hold on."

When I am happy,
I am finally, completely
At home in my own skin—
A house with all its windows open.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'When I am happy,'

responses.text:
When I am happy,
The world blooms in technicolor hues,
Ordinary moments transform to magic,
And the weight I didn't know I carried
Slips from my shoulders like snow from a roof.

When I am happy,
Time stretches like taffy pulled between fingers,
Seconds become treasures I can hold,
And my laughter bubbles up from depths
I'd forgotten existed within me.

When I am happy,
I see reflections of joy in strangers' eyes,
In the dance of leaves across pavement,
In the steam rising from my morning cup—
Everything a mirror to this lightness of being.

When I am happy,
I am most myself, most human,
Most connected to the universe's pulse,
A constellation of moments strung together,
Shining bright against life's vast darkness.

When I am happy,
I become a river flowing toward the sea,
Unstoppable, glistening under sunlight,
Carrying fragments of joy to shores unknown.

When I am happy,
My bones become hollow like a bird's,
Filled with nothing but possibility and air,
Ready to take flight at the slightest breeze.

When I am happy,
I collect small moments like seashells—
The perfect foam on my coffee,
A text message from someone I love,
The way shadows play across my bedroom floor.

When I am happy,
I forgive the world its trespasses,
I forgive myself for yesterday's mistakes,
I see clearly how little we need
To make this life worth living.

When I am happy,
I am both more and less myself—
Expanded beyond my usual boundaries,
Yet distilled to my purest essence,
A paradox wrapped in a smile.

When I am happy,
I wear my skin like a comfortable coat,
Tailored perfectly to my soul.
The universe conspires with my breathing—
Inhale stardust, exhale gratitude.

When I am happy,
My heart beats in sync with distant drums,
Ancestral rhythms I've always known
But sometimes forget to listen for
In the cacophony of daily demands.

When I am happy,
Memories lose their sharp edges,
Future anxieties dissolve like sugar in tea.
I exist perfectly in the present moment,
Neither rushing forward nor looking back.

When I am happy,
I become a lighthouse for others lost at sea,
My joy a beacon cutting through fog and storm,
Offering safe harbor without conditions,
Asking nothing in return but to share this warmth.

When I am happy,
I finally understand that this, too, shall pass—
And that knowledge makes it all the more precious,
A butterfly perched briefly on an open palm
Before taking flight once more.

When I am happy,
The clock hands slow their relentless march,
And I become a collector of sensations—
The rough texture of tree bark beneath fingertips,
The symphony of birdsong at dawn,
The perfect weight of a book in my lap.

When I am happy,
I carry no maps or destinations,
Just the compass of my curiosity
Pointing always toward wonder.
Each crossroad a gift rather than a choice.

When I am happy,
I remember how my grandmother's hands
Smelled of cinnamon and patience,
How she taught me that joy is not found
But created, moment by careful moment.

When I am happy,
I become a vessel for light,
Transparent and open,
Neither clinging to this feeling
Nor fearing its inevitable departure.

When I am happy,
I am most mortal, most alive,
Most aware of time's sweet brevity—
This fleeting human experience
Suddenly enough, suddenly everything.

When I am happy,
The universe shrinks to fit inside my chest,
Stars and galaxies nestled between ribs,
Black holes transformed to fountains of light.
My body becomes a cosmos of its own making.

When I am happy,
Words taste different on my tongue—
Sweeter, rounder, more substantial,
As if language itself has been waiting
For this exact moment to reveal its true nature.

When I am happy,
I forgive the rain for falling,
The night for its darkness,
The winter for its cold—
Each element necessary in the greater pattern.

When I am happy,
I can trace the invisible threads
That connect me to strangers passing on the street,
To ancestors long turned to dust,
To future generations not yet imagined.

When I am happy,
I finally understand that joy is not the absence of sorrow
But its complement, its necessary twin—
Two dancers in perfect opposition,
Creating between them the fullness of being human.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A mirror of what I could be,
Reflections dancing in the light,
Of futures yet to take their flight.

The path ahead unfolds like streams,
Carrying whispers of my dreams,
Each step a choice, each breath a chance,
In this mysterious cosmic dance.

Before me stands I see,
The shadows of my ancestry,
Their hopes and fears now carved in me,
A living bridge of history.

The mountains of my doubt arise,
Yet courage paints the morning skies,
And in this moment, clear and free,
I glimpse the soul that's meant to be.

Before me stands I see,
The ocean's vast infinity,
Waves crashing on the shores of time,
Eternal rhythms, so sublime.

The grains of sand beneath my feet,
Countless lives that I shall meet,
Each one a story, each a star,
Illuminating who we are.

Before me stands I see,
A forest of possibility,
Where branches reach toward the light,
And roots dig deep into the night.

I am both witness and the seen,
The spaces that exist between,
The breath that fills the morning air,
The silent prayer that I am there.

Before me stands I see,
A child with skinned and bloody knee,
Tears welling in familiar eyes,
A younger self I recognize.

Time folds like paper in the wind,
What's yet to come, what might have been,
Collapse into this single point,
Where past and future now conjoint.

Before me stands I see,
The weight of all identity,
The masks we wear, the roles we play,
The truths we hide in light of day.

I reach across the veil of years,
To touch this ghost of hopes and fears,
And in that touch, at last I find,
The healing of a fractured mind.

Before me stands I see,
A mountain carved from destiny,
Its jagged peaks pierce leaden skies,
Where ancient wisdom never dies.

The climb begins with single step,
A promise to myself I've kept,
To face the heights with steady breath,
Embracing life, defying death.

Before me stands I see,
The person I was meant to be,
Forged in fire, tempered by rain,
Transformed through joy, refined by pain.

The summit calls with siren song,
I've wandered paths both short and long,
And now I stand at crossroads bare,
With courage enough to finally dare.

Before me stands I see,
The dance of synchronicity,
Moments strung like pearls on thread,
Connecting all that's done and said.

The universe in single drop,
A clock whose hands will never stop,
The spiral pattern's gentle curve,
In which all matter must observe.

Before me stands I see,
The paradox of being free,
Bound by laws we can't perceive,
Yet masters of what we believe.

I am the watcher and the watched,
The lock that's opened, door unlatched,
The question and its own reply,
The ground below, the endless sky.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A mirror of my soul unfree,
Reflecting back what I might be,
If courage found its way to me.

The shadow self, the brighter twin,
The person I have always been,
Yet hidden under layers thin,
Of doubt and fear and worldly din.

Before me stands I see,
A future waiting patiently,
A thousand paths, a thousand keys,
To unlock doors of destiny.

So forward now I choose to go,
Embrace the self I've yet to know,
For in this vision clear I grow,
As past and future seamless flow.

Before me stands I see,
The ancient oak, resilient tree,
Whose branches reach toward the sky,
While roots sink deep where secrets lie.

It witnessed centuries unfold,
Stood firm through tales now left untold,
A silent keeper of the land,
Unmoved by time's relentless hand.

Before me stands I see,
A teacher of eternity,
Who whispers through its rustling leaves,
"Be patient, child, like me, believe."

I press my palm against its bark,
Connect across the light and dark,
Two beings sharing sacred space,
Both temporary in this place.

Before me stands I see,
The vastness of infinity,
A cosmos swirling, stars ablaze,
Across the void, a cosmic maze.

Galaxies spiral, nebulae glow,
Celestial dancers in cosmic show,
Expanding outward without end,
Where time and space forever blend.

Before me stands I see,
My insignificance and majesty,
A paradox of dust and light,
Awakened to the endless night.

For I contain these stars within,
My atoms forged where suns begin,
Connected to the cosmic whole,
A universe inside my soul.

Before me stands I see,
The child I used to be,
With wonder-widened eyes aglow,
And heart untouched by sorrow's flow.

That innocence I thought was lost,
Surrendered as a heavy cost,
Of growing up and growing old,
As life's harsh lessons took their hold.

Before me stands I see,
A chance for reconciliation's key,
To heal the fractures of the years,
Embrace both laughter, love, and tears.

So hand in hand we walk as one,
The journey ended, just begun,
As wisdom meets with innocence,
And makes a soul complete, immense.

Before me stands I see,
A mountain of uncertainty,
Jagged peaks of doubt and fear,
The summit lost in clouds unclear.

Each step requires a choice to make,
Which path to follow, which to take,
No map to guide my weary feet,
No guarantee of summit sweet.

Before me stands I see,
The test of my own bravery,
To climb despite the daunting height,
To trust myself through darkest night.

So forward now, one step, then two,
The mountain's challenge to pursue,
For only by ascending high,
Can I touch fingers to the sky.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A mirror of myself, unmasked and true,
Reflecting back the soul that yearns to be
Unfettered from the chains of what I knew.

The shadow and the light in equal measure,
A tapestry of choices, wounds, and dreams,
The person I've become—both pain and pleasure,
More complex than the surface ever seems.

Before me stands I see,
The future waiting, patient as the dawn,
A thousand paths that stretch eternally,
Each step a verse in songs yet to be drawn.

I face myself with courage, not with fear,
Embracing all I was and will become,
The stranger and the friend, both far and near,
The scattered notes that form my life's sweet hum.

Before me stands I see,
The mountain's ancient face against the sky,
Indifferent to my human fragility,
Yet calling forth my spirit to climb high.

Granite wisdom carved by time's slow hand,
Patient teacher of persistence and of strength,
Rooted deep within the trembling land,
Stretching skyward to impossible length.

Before me stands I see,
A challenge and a sanctuary both,
A testament to nature's majesty,
Silent keeper of an ageless oath.

I am but breath against its weathered stone,
A moment's whisper in its endless days,
Yet in its presence, I am not alone—
We share the sun's warm touch, the cloud's soft haze.

Before me stands I see,
A doorway to what might or might not be,
Its frame a border between now and then,
Between the known and what lies beyond ken.

Neither open nor fully closed it waits,
Patient as centuries, still as night,
Guardian of possibilities and fates,
Nexus where shadows dance with light.

Before me stands I see,
The question that demands I make reply—
Shall I cross over or shall I flee
Back to the comfort where no dangers lie?

The handle cool beneath my trembling palm,
The hinges singing songs of rust and time,
My heartbeat echoing like a solemn psalm,
As courage and fear together climb.

Before me stands I see,
The ocean's endless conversation with the shore,
Whispering secrets of eternity,
Then roaring truths we cannot ignore.

Blue-green vastness cradling ancient life,
Rocking creatures in its salty womb,
Healing wounds with gentle foam, yet rife
With storms that send great vessels to their doom.

Before me stands I see,
A mirror to the sky's inconstant face,
Reflecting clouds that drift so carelessly,
While holding depths no human can embrace.

I am drawn to wade into its cool embrace,
To taste the salt that flavors all our tears,
To find myself a temporary place
In rhythms that have pulsed ten thousand years.

Before me stands I see,
A child with eyes that hold tomorrow's light,
Small hands that grasp at possibilities,
A heart untouched by cynicism's blight.

This tiny being—half stranger, half my soul—
Mirrors back the wonder I once knew,
Reminds me of the stories yet untold,
Of journeys waiting, skies forever blue.

Before me stands I see,
The purest form of hope in human shape,
A chance to bend the arc of destiny,
To heal old wounds and ancient wrongs escape.

What wisdom can I offer this young mind?
What courage can I model for this heart?
What legacy of kindness leave behind
When time decrees that we must walk apart?

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Before me stands I see,'

responses.text:
Before me stands I see,
A mirror of what I could be,
Reflections dancing in the glass,
Of futures present, futures past.

The shadow of my former self,
Stares back with eyes of weathered health,
Whispers secrets only known,
To hearts that wander all alone.

Before me stands I see,

And paths both straight and intertwined.

What courage must I summon now,
To face what stands before my gaze?
A journey mapped in silent stars,
Through tangled nights and sunlit days.

Before me stands I see,
The person I am yet to be.

Before me stands I see,
The ancient oak, three centuries strong,
Its branches reach toward heaven's door,
Roots deeper than my sorrows long.

Its bark, a text of weathered time,
Tells stories of the changing world,
Of lovers' names carved in its skin,
Of storms survived, of leaves unfurled.

Before me stands I see,
A witness to humanity,
Unmoved by our brief flickering,
Yet holding space for what might be.

I press my palm against its core,
And feel the pulse of something true,
A wisdom older than my bones,
A patience I am passing through.

Before me stands I see,
A teacher of eternity.

Before me stands I see,
The vast expanse of possibility,
A canvas blank yet full of life,
Where dreams and fears wage silent strife.

The horizon bends with golden light,
As day prepares to yield to night,
And in this space between the hours,
I feel the universe's powers.

Before me stands I see,
My younger self, my older too,
The versions of me never born,
And those I've shed like morning dew.

What alchemy transforms the soul?
What magic turns the partial whole?
Perhaps the answer lies not in sight,
But in the journey toward the light.

Before me stands I see,
The endless ocean of what could be.

Before me stands I see,
The wreckage of what used to be,
A city turned to silent stone,
Where echoes wander, quite alone.

The broken towers touch the sky,
Like fingers asking simply, why?
The streets now rivers made of dust,
Where memories crumble into rust.

Before me stands I see,
The cost of human vanity,

Yet in this desolation grows,
A tender green that gently shows,

Before me stands I see,

Before me stands I see,

Those eyes reflect what I've become,
The battles lost, the victories won,

Before me stands I see,
A judge both merciful and true,

'What have you done?' the child demands,

I kneel to meet those stellar eyes,
And search for words beyond disguise.

Before me stands I see,
The purest form of honesty.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'One dark, dark night--it was long ago,'

responses.text:
One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When shadows danced on walls of stone,
And whispers carried through the snow,
Of secrets buried, never known.

The moon hung veiled behind the clouds,
As ancient trees creaked in the wind,
And time itself seemed disavowed,
Where endings and beginnings twinned.

A distant bell tolled thrice and ceased,
Its echo lingering in the air,
As something stirred from sleep released,
Awakening from its hidden lair.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When I first glimpsed the other side,
Where memories like rivers flow,
And ghosts of former selves reside.

I carry still that midnight hour,
Its darkness etched upon my soul,
A moment of awakened power,
That made my fractured spirit whole.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I wandered through the misted vale,
Where ancient oaks stood row by row,
And stars told their forgotten tale.

The world was young when I was old,
My memories stretched beyond the veil,
Of histories that time has sold,
And legends that will never pale.

I heard the earth's primeval song,
A melody of fire and stone,
Of creatures gone, both weak and strong,
Whose bones now rest, to dust now grown.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I touched the fabric of all things,
And felt the cosmic rivers flow,
Through mortal hearts and angel wings.

Perhaps it was a dream, or truth,
This journey through the endless dark,
A glimpse of age, a taste of youth,
A moment's bright, eternal spark.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
When childhood fears still ruled my mind,
The creaking house, the window's glow,
The shadows that would shift and wind.

My grandfather's old rocking chair,
Swayed gently though no one was there,
His pipe still warm upon the stair,
Though he had passed the year before.

The mantel clock struck midnight clear,
Its chimes like footsteps drawing near,
I clutched my quilt with rising fear,
As winter rattled at the door.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I learned that time is but a veil,
That love persists through grief and woe,
And memories never truly fail.

For in that darkness, cold and deep,
I felt his hand upon my hair,
A gentle blessing, soft as sleep,
Proof that the dead still linger there.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
Beneath a sky of shattered glass,
Where comets streaked in fiery show,
And planets spun in cosmic mass.

I stood alone on barren shore,
Where ocean met the endless sand,
A witness to the ancient lore,
Of water claiming once-dry land.

The lighthouse beam cut through the haze,
A single eye that swept the deep,
Illuminating phantom ways,
Where sailors lost forever sleep.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I found a message in the tide,
A bottle's secret undertow,
Had carried from the other side.

The words within, now faded pale,
Were written in a hand like mine,
A future self who told the tale,
Of how this moment would align.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
The city slept beneath the rain,
While streetlamps cast their amber glow,
On cobblestones and window pane.

A carriage clattered down the street,
Its lanterns swinging with each stride,
The horse's slow and steady beat,
A rhythm from another tide.

I followed it through twisting ways,
Past buildings bent with age and wear,
Through alleys thick with fog and haze,
To places few would ever dare.

One dark, dark night--it was long ago,
I crossed the threshold of what's known,
To where the boundaries overflow,
And time itself is overthrown.

Sometimes I wonder if I've stayed,
Still wandering that phantom track,
Or if I've somehow found my way,
From that dark night, at last, back.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire:
Dancer of destruction, painter of light,
Your crimson fingers reach for the sky,
Consume the darkness, chase away night,
With crackling whispers, your embers sigh.

Ancient element, both friend and foe,
You warm our homes yet scorch our lands,
In your presence we watch shadows grow,
As you transform all with hungry hands.

From spark to inferno, your life unfolds,
Devour oxygen, breathe smoke and ash,
Yet in your wake, new life still holds—
Renewal rises from what you've dashed.

Fire: cleansing force of transformation,
You remind us of life's brief duration.

Fire:
A primal hunger, never satisfied,
Licking at the edges of existence,
With tongues of gold and amber, deified,
The first gift stolen, divine persistence.

You dance between creation and collapse,
A paradox of comfort and of fear,
The hearth that warms, the forest that perhaps
Will fall to your insatiable frontier.

I've watched you claim cathedrals, homes, and dreams,
Yet from your fury, phoenix-like we rise,
Rebuild from ashes, stronger than it seems—
The human spirit your heat purifies.

In you, I see our passions mirrored clear:
Wild, untamed, beautiful, and severe.

Fire:
Elemental whisper, ancient might,
Born from friction, spark to flame,
Illuminating darkest night,
Never twice burning the same.

In hearths you comfort, bringing peace,
In forests rage with thoughtless wrath,
Your hunger knows no swift release,
Leaving carbon in your path.

Yet in your wake, the soil renews,
Seeds crack open, life returns,
The cycle that you introduce—
Destruction where creation yearns.

We gather 'round your dancing light,
Telling stories through the ages,
Drawing close on winter nights,
Your glow upon our faces.

Fire: keeper of our earliest days,
Forever changing, forever stays.

Fire:
Cradled in the palm of human progress,
You've carried us from caves to stars above.
Your warmth, a blessing; your rage, a reckless
Destroyer of what we've built with love.

I've seen you in the passion of lovers' eyes,
In angry words that scorch and leave their mark,
In revolution's torch that never dies,
In dying suns that blaze against the dark.

You are the breath of dragons in our tales,
The burning bush where gods have spoken true,
The forge where strongest metal never fails,
The sacred flame that always burns anew.

Within each heart, a spark of you remains—
The will to fight when only hope sustains.

Fire:
Neither friend nor enemy but teacher,
Your lessons etched in ash and smoke,
You are both healer and beseecher,
Of respect from all the folk.

From campfires where our stories grew,
To wildfires claiming ancient trees,
Your duality shines through—
Life and death in your decrees.

I've held you close on coldest nights,
And fled your wrath in summer's heat,
Watched as you claimed your sovereign rights
To transform all that you meet.

In metaphor, you burn within—
Passion, anger, love, and pain,
The crucible where we begin
To understand what we contain.

Fire: keeper of time's oldest art,
The alchemy of change at heart.

Yet without you, we'd still in caverns roam.

Devour me, transform me, leave no trace,
Of who I was before your fierce embrace.

Fire:
Elemental whisper from creation's dawn,
Red-orange deity with crackling laugh,
Devourer of oxygen, child of spark,
Tempestuous dancer on history's path.

In your heat, civilizations rose,
Beside your glow, stories were first told,
Through your forge, metals bent and flowed,
With your warmth, we survived the bitter cold.

Yet you consume without remorse or thought,
Leaving charcoal memories in your wake,
Forests to ashes, lives to naught,
A hungry god no offering can slake.

Beautiful destroyer, necessary end,
In your burning, rebirth always hides,
Phoenix-maker, transformer, friend,
Primordial power where truth resides.

Fire:
A single match against the void,
Flickering defiance in darkness vast,
Tiny revolution of heat unbound,
Ancient memory from eons past.

I have held you in my trembling palms,
Watched you consume what no longer serves,
Letters from lovers who've done me harm,
Photographs fading like dying nerves.

You were there when mountains formed and fell,
When asteroids scarred the infant Earth,
You'll remain when final stories tell,
Of humanity's end and rebirth.

Neither good nor evil, simply true,
Transformation's agent, pure and bright,
I surrender what I cling to,
To dance with you through one more night.

Fire:
They warned me not to play with you,
Yet here I stand, hands outstretched,
Toward your hypnotic orange-blue,
My caution thoroughly wretched.

You speak in crackles, hisses, pops,
Ancient language of destruction and birth,
Consumer of forests, clearer of crops,
Bringer of fertility back to earth.

In hearths you're tamed, in lanterns caged,
A servant to human ambition and need,
But wild, you've never truly aged,
Primordial force that cannot concede.

I see in you my own heart's desire,
Untamable, fierce, forever free,
Both creator and funeral pyre,
The element I wish to be.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Fire:'

responses.text:
Fire:
Dancing embers in the night,
Flickering tongues of orange light.
Crackling whispers, ancient song,
Primal power, fierce and strong.

Consumer of forests, cleaner of plains,
Destroyer and creator in equal refrains.
Warmth for the weary, light in the dark,
Civilization's first crucial spark.

In hearths we tame you, in wildness you roam,
Both servant and master, both stranger and home.
Your hunger insatiable, your passion untamed,
Your beauty and danger can never be claimed.

Element eternal, transformation's embrace,
You turn solid to ash with effortless grace.
In your presence we gather, in your absence we yearn,
For the lessons you teach as you flicker and burn.

Fire:
Molten memories cascade through fingertips,
As ancestral wisdom ignites within our bones.
You were our first revolution,
The radical transformation that birthed humanity.

You devour indiscriminately—
Forests, cities, photographs, love letters—
Yet from your ravenous consumption
Comes the fertile ash of new beginnings.

I have seen you dance in lovers' eyes,
Felt you burn in the throat of justice,
Watched you smolder in the hands of the patient,
And explode in the hearts of the oppressed.

You are revolution and revelation,
Destruction and purification,
The end of what was,
And the violent birth of what might be.

In your light, we see ourselves truly—
Temporary, transformable, terrified, tremendous—
Creatures of carbon returning to stardust,
Burning briefly against the cold universe.

Fire:
A whisper becomes a roar,
Gentle touch turns to consuming embrace.
You begin as possibility,
A spark, a promise, a potential.

How quickly you transform—
From friend to foe,
From tool to tyrant,
From hearth to horror.

In your hunger I see my own;
In your restlessness, my ambition;
In your wild dance, my untamed heart;
In your destruction, my capacity for change.

You are the first storyteller,
Shadows dancing on cave walls,
Faces illuminated in primal communion,
Secrets whispered in the safety of your glow.

We have carried you across oceans,
Built temples to your power,
Feared and worshipped your unpredictability.
Yet still you remain untamed—

Ancient element, oldest companion,
Beautiful terror, necessary danger,
Reminder that creation and destruction
Are merely different faces of the same force.

Fire:
In the palm of night, you unfold
like a flower blooming backward,
petals of heat and light
curling inward to your hungry core.

You speak in consonants—
crackle, pop, hiss—
a language older than words,
a sermon of transformation.

I have seen you birth civilizations,
forge steel and glass and will,
and I have seen you reduce
centuries to cinders in moments.

You are the great equalizer,
returning all things to their elements,
reminding emperors and beggars alike
of their shared impermanence.

Yet in your destruction lies renewal;
in your consumption, continuation;
in your hungry mouth, the seeds
of forests waiting to be born.

Perhaps this is why we stare,
transfixed by your hypnotic dance—
recognizing in your brief, brilliant life
the perfect metaphor for our own.

Fire:
Neither friend nor enemy,
But ancient teacher whose lessons
Burn themselves into memory.

I have held you in my hands,
A fragile, flickering thing,
Only to watch you devour mountains
With the same casual hunger.

You are the threshold guardian,
Standing between raw and cooked,
Between nature and culture,
Between the world as given
And the world as made.

In your presence, we become human;
Gathered around your light,
Sharing stories, sharing warmth,
Forging bonds stronger than blood.

Yet you remain wild at heart,
A tamed wolf that remembers
Its freedom in dreams,
Ready to return to wilderness
At the slightest provocation.

Element of paradox—
Destroyer that creates,
Consumer that nourishes,
Ending that begins—
You teach us that transformation
Always comes with sacrifice,
That to become, we must first burn.

Purifying, cleansing heat,

In your glow, we gather close,
Share our stories, fears expose.

Until your final spark is done.

Fire:
Elemental fury, amber glow,
Beneath the stars your embers grow.
Memories dance in your light,
Shadows retreating from your might.

You forge the steel, you shape our will,
Destructive force, yet sacred still.
In your heart, transformation lives—
You take away, yet also gives.

I've watched you claim the tallest trees,
Roaring wild and running free.
I've held you close on winter nights,
When frost commands and cold bites.

Both servant, master, friend and foe,
The ancient dance we've come to know.
In your reflection I can see
The primal truth that burns in me.

Fire:
Born from spark, a hungry child,
Nurtured by breath, growing wild.
Crackling whispers, secrets told
In languages both new and old.

Your hunger knows no bound or chain,
Consumes all life, leaves ashen rain.
Yet in destruction, hope remains—
For after fire, life sustains.

In hearths you comfort, warm, and light,
A beacon through the darkest night.
In forests, cleanse the dying floor,
So seeds may sprout and life restore.

Duality in every flame,
Creation, death—they are the same.
Your lesson burns into our soul:
To truly live is to be whole.

Fire:
Sister of wind, daughter of sun,
Your dance began when time begun.
Flickering spirit, never still,
Defying capture, bending will.

I've seen you in the lover's gaze,
In passion's heat, in anger's blaze.
In revolution's burning cry,
In stars that punctuate the sky.

You dwell within the poet's verse,
The artist's vision, pure and terse.
In every heart that dares to dream,
Beneath the surface, you gleam.

Consume me not, but light my way,
Transform my night into the day.
Teach me to burn but not destroy,
To warm the world with sacred joy.

Fire:
Voracious spirit, untamed soul,
Within your heart, a cosmic goal.
To purify what came before,
To clear the path for something more.

I watch your fingers reach and climb,
Defying gravity and time.
Your colors shift from gold to blue,
Revealing depths of hidden hue.

In you, I see our human state—
The power to create, negate.
The wisdom of the phoenix taught:
From ashes, resurrection brought.

We fear your touch, yet seek your light,
A paradox of wrong and right.
In every ending lies rebirth,
As flames return to fertile earth.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'You can hear the excitement start to linger as the early morning train departs.'

responses.text:
# Morning Departure

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
Whispers of adventure curl like steam,
rising from coffee cups and hopeful hearts.

Steel wheels kiss the tracks with promises,
rhythmic clacking counts the miles ahead.
Windows frame the waking landscape,
where dawn paints fields in gold and red.

Strangers share glances, brief connections,
all bound by the journey's sacred thread.
Some return to lives well-traveled,
others leap toward the unknown instead.

The conductor's call echoes through carriages,
a modern psalm of movement and of change.
And in that liminal space between stations,
we find ourselves gloriously estranged.

You can hear the excitement start to linger,
long after the platform disappears from sight.
It hums beneath your skin like electricity,
guiding you toward morning's gentle light.

# Departure's Promise

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
The station's breath, a misty sigh,
releasing dreams from sleepy hearts.

Metal giants yawn and stretch,
shaking off the night's embrace.
Passengers clutch tickets like talismans,
their faces maps of time and place.

Destinations whispered like prayers,
geographies of hope and fear.
The world outside still half-asleep,
while journeys crystallize in here.

We carry more than luggage in our hands—
we bear the weight of what's to come.
Each mile marks a transformation,
each ticket, a kingdom to become.

Windows mirror faces caught between
what was and what might someday be.
The tracks ahead, a silver promise,
a path to who we're meant to see.

You can hear the excitement start to linger,
in the space between departure and arrival's art,
where possibility rides the rails of morning,
and every journey is a fresh start.

# Iron Symphony

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
A mechanical beast awakening,
tearing silence into gleaming parts.

Steam rises like collective breath,
the platform's edge a boundary crossed.
Some faces pressed against cold windows,
others turned away from what they've lost.

The station clock surrenders time
to movement's more honest measure.
Distance becomes our new currency,
landscape our ephemeral treasure.

People clutch their paper tickets,
those flimsy contracts with fate.
Destinations printed in bold promise,
while the journey refuses to wait.

Suitcases filled with necessary things,
pockets holding what we cannot pack—
memories, fears, and secret hopes
that follow us down the track.

You can hear the excitement start to linger
in the rhythm of the wheels' refrain.
Life suspended between stations,
reborn in the body of the train.

# Threshold Crossing

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
A chorus of wheels on metal veins,
singing to still-slumbering hearts.

Dew-kissed windows frame the world
in panels of passing possibility.
The day not yet decided,
hangs between what was and what will be.

Strangers share this liminal space,
each carrying stories untold.
Bound together by temporary purpose,
their destinies briefly controlled.

The conductor moves like a timekeeper,
validating our right to transition.
Tickets punched become small ceremonies,
marking passage with quiet precision.

Cities shrink to miniature memories,
as countryside expands to fill the view.
Distance becomes a kind of medicine,
healing what staying still cannot do.

You can hear the excitement start to linger
in the spaces between each breath.
Every departure a small rebellion
against stillness, against death.

# Morning Alchemy

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs.
A metallic serpent slithering forward,
carrying fragments of countless hearts.

Fog parts like theater curtains,
revealing scenes of lives in transit.
The world outside still half-dreaming,
while we move with determined magic.

Through windows, reality transforms—
familiar landscapes rendered strange.
Distance works its subtle alchemy,
turning mundane into exchange.

The rhythm beneath becomes a heartbeat,
a shared pulse among scattered souls.
Strangers united in forward motion,
temporarily sharing common goals.

Some read books to pass the time,
others stare at reflections in glass.
Watching themselves disappear
as miles and memories amass.

You can hear the excitement start to linger
in the clatter of this iron horse.
Carrying us toward new beginnings,
fueled by hope and subtle force.

A metallic beast awakening with the dawn,
Breathing steam into the half-light.

Platform faces blur like watercolors,
Dew-kissed goodbyes and coffee-scented promises.
The conductor's whistle pierces the fog—
A clarion call to adventure.

Inside, we are strangers bound by rails,
Our stories intersecting for miles unmeasured.
Outside, the world transforms:
Concrete jungles melt to emerald fields,
Then rise as mountains against cerulean skies.

Time becomes elastic, stretched between stations,
Compressed in tunnels of momentary darkness.
We are travelers suspended between was and will be,
Carrying yesterday's memories in worn suitcases,
Tomorrow's dreams in anxious hearts.

Listen—beneath the rhythm of the tracks,
The whispered promise of elsewhere calls.

Departure's Promise

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs,
Leaving behind sleep-heavy towns
And dreams still clinging to pillowcases.

Steel serpent slithering through landscapes,
Swallowing miles with mechanical hunger,
Carrying souls in its segmented belly
Toward futures unknown and unnamed.

The windows frame a world in motion—
Blurred trees, forgotten stations,
Lives glimpsed for seconds then lost,
Like thoughts that visit then vanish.

Inside this vessel of collective escape,
Strangers avoid eyes yet share breath,
Each passenger an island connected
By the same churning ocean of wheels.

The excitement is not in the leaving,
Nor entirely in where we might arrive,
But in this sacred space between worlds,
Where possibility outweighs memory,
And even the most cautious heart
Dares to imagine what waits at journey's end.

Threshold Crossing

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs,
Chasing the sun across sleepy plains,
Waking birds scatter from telegraph wires.

The platform's farewell echoes fade
As distance grows between what was
And what might be—that sacred space
Where possibility dances with fear.

I count the rhythms of the track,
A meditation of metal on metal,
While fields and towns blur together
Like memories losing their edges.

Fellow travelers, strangers in transition,
Each face a story I'll never fully know—
The businessman with worried eyes,
The young couple with intertwined fingers,
The old woman clutching photographs.

We are all suspended between worlds,
Neither here nor there, but somewhere in between,
Where the excitement lingers like morning mist,
And even the most jaded heart remembers
How it feels to cross a threshold,
To become, for one brief journey,
Purely potential.

Whistle and Rail

You can hear the excitement start to linger
as the early morning train departs,
A mechanical exhalation of purpose,
Punctuality made manifest in motion.

Platform goodbyes shrink to pinpoints,
Handkerchiefs waving like surrendered flags.
The world outside begins its backward dance,
A cinema reel of landscapes in reverse.

Within these metal confines,
We are temporary nomads,
Carrying our lives in overhead compartments,
Our destinations tucked in ticket pockets.

The clickety-clack becomes a heartbeat,
A lullaby of industrial progress
Rocking us between consciousness and dream.
We drift in this liminal space,
Neither where we were nor where we're bound.

The excitement isn't shouted or proclaimed,
But whispered in the steam between stations,
In the possibility that awaits at journey's end,
In the freedom found between departures and arrivals,
Where we are, for precious hours,
Unfindable and therefore infinite.

Time is not a river but an ocean,

We have met before—

WE HAVE MET BEFORE

In the library of forgotten things,

We have met before in fractured mirrors,

We have met before—

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
I saw an old cottage of clay,
Weathered by time's gentle hand,
Where memories of yesteryears lay,
Rooted deep in forgotten land.

Its windows like eyes half-closed with age,
Gazed upon meadows once bright with play,
Its walls held secrets, page by page,
Of lives that flourished then ebbed away.

The chimney, crooked but standing still,

Stood sentinel upon the hill,
Watching as decades drifted by.

I wondered of the hands that built,
This humble haven long ago,
Of tears that fell and blood that spilt,
To make a home where love could grow.

That cottage speaks of simpler days,
Before our world of steel and glass,
When people walked in slower ways,
And took the time to feel life pass.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Forgotten by progress, by future, by past.
Its walls whispered stories of those gone away,
Of dreams too fragile, too tender to last.

The roof sagged inward like shoulders of grief,
Doorway agape like a silent, parched mouth.
Time had become both the thief and the thief's
Accomplice, as north wind blew in from the south.

Wildflowers reclaimed what humans forsook,
Vines wrapped their fingers through cracks in the stone.
Nature, the patient and diligent crook,
Slowly transforming the house to a home.

Did children once laugh in those shadowed rooms?
Did lovers exchange their first trembling kiss?
Did someone plant hope that never did bloom,
In soil that promised more than this?

I touched the rough wall, felt centuries pass
Beneath my fingertips, ancient and new.
A cottage of clay—a mirror, a glass—
Reflecting all we build and undo.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
A testament to hands long still,
Its earthen walls, worn and gray,
Standing defiant against the hill.

The morning light caressed its face,
Illuminating cracks and scars,
Yet in its humble, weathered grace,
It shone more brilliant than the stars.

No architect had drawn its lines,
No blueprint guided careful hands,
Just human need and grand designs
Formed from the language of the land.

The hearth within, now cold and bare,
Once danced with flames of amber light,
While voices filled the evening air
With tales to ward off coming night.

From earth we rise, to earth return,
This cottage knows what we forget:
That in simplicity we learn
The truths we're too quick to regret.

So stand, dear cottage, made of clay,
Remind us of our humble start,
That we are merely guests who stay
Upon this world that holds our heart.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Half-hidden by ivy and time,
Where shadows and sunlight would play
In patterns of rhythm and rhyme.

The door hung askew on its hinge,
A sentinel tired but proud,
The threshold worn thin at the fringe
By footsteps no longer allowed.

Inside, where the dust settled deep,
The echoes of laughter still clung
To corners where memories sleep,
And cobwebs like curtains were hung.

A chair by the hearth sat alone,

While wind through the rafters would moan
A lullaby solemn and brash.

Who dwelled in this sanctuary small?

Did love ever grace this old wall
Before it grew weary and old?

I stood there as daylight grew dim,
Communing with ghosts of before,
And felt my own story begin
To merge with the cottage of yore.

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Crumbling beneath heaven's gaze,
A relic of some bygone day,
Lost in time's mysterious haze.

Its walls, once sturdy, now decay,
Yet something sacred lingers there—
A presence words cannot convey,
That fills the still and ancient air.

Perhaps it's souls who couldn't leave,
Or memories trapped in mortar's grip,
Or dreams that humans dare believe
Could outlast their mortality's slip.

A sparrow nests where people slept,
Wild roses climb where children played,
Rain seeps through spots where mothers wept,
As nature claims what humans made.

I touch the clay, it warms my hand,
As if the cottage understands
That I, too, am of dust and sand,
Just passing through these borrowed lands.

We share this truth, the house and I:
That all returns to earth someday,
Yet beauty lives in how we try
To shape our temporary clay.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I saw an old cottage of clay,'

responses.text:
I saw an old cottage of clay,

Though crumbling aloud,

What humanity tames,

I wonder who sheltered within,

The cottage still stands,

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Hidden where wild roses sway.

At the edge of the ancient wood,
A relic of some bygone day.

The thatched roof, sagging with age,
Held stories on each weathered page.

As if the house itself had grown
From earth—a natural heritage.

Inside those walls, what lives were led?
What prayers whispered, what tears shed?
Generations passed through that door,
Their footprints worn into the floor,
Their dreams hanging overhead.

Perhaps in this forgotten place,
I glimpse mortality's true face—
For we, like cottages of clay,
Are formed, stand firm, then fade away,
Leaving just whispers of our grace.

THE CLAY DWELLING

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Sunken and slouched in the dell,
Its shoulders hunched against the wind,
As if time itself had pinned
Its weight upon this earthen shell.

Handprints of builders long since gone
Still visible in hardened walls,
Earth mixed with straw and human sweat,
A monument we now forget
As progress makes its siren calls.

The door, a mouth half-open wide,
Breathes stories of a simpler age,
When hands that built were hands that sowed,
When life moved at a gentler mode,
And wisdom came with growing sage.

I touch the surface, rough and cool,
And feel connection to the past,
This humble home of common soil
Built through honest human toil,
A beauty made to truly last.

EARTHEN MEMORIES

I saw an old cottage of clay,
And stopped to watch the shadows play
Across its face of russet brown,
Forgotten at the edge of town,
A sentinel of yesterday.

Its mud-brick walls, sun-baked and strong,
Had sheltered lives both short and long.
The fingerprints of craftsmen dead
Still marked each brick and overhead
The rafters hummed an ancient song.

What hands had shaped this dwelling place?
What joys and sorrows left their trace?
Perhaps a child's first stumbling step,
A mother's tears when loved ones slept,
A father's pride, a bride's embrace.

We build our homes from earth and clay,
Then back to earth we make our way.
This cottage stands as witness still
To how we shape the world until
We too become the dust of day.

CLAY FOUNDATIONS

I saw an old cottage of clay,
Eroded by wind, sun, and rain.
Its walls—once straight and firmly set—

With stubborn will to still remain.

Of generations trapped inside.
We are but cottages of clay,
With souls that cannot be denied.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Night Funeral

Silent procession under starless skies,
Footsteps muffled by grief's heavy cloak.
Candles flicker like souls not yet gone,
Their light a bridge between worlds.

Black umbrellas bloom like midnight flowers,
Sheltering tears from heaven's watchful gaze.
The earth waits, mouth open, patient and cold,
To receive what was never truly ours.

Mournful hymns float on midnight air,
Words ancient as sorrow itself.
The box descends, wood against earth,
A final percussion in life's fading symphony.

We stand as shadows among shadows,
Bearing witness to time's cruel passage.
Night funeral—where darkness meets darkness,
And we learn that goodbye is a language
With no translation into comfort.

PASSAGE

They carried him through moonlight,
six men with shoulders bent
beneath the weight of absence.
The night held its breath.

Stars punctured the darkness
like distant witnesses.
The world felt inside-out,
all its secrets exposed.

I watched from the hillside,
a ghost among the living.
The procession moved like water,
dark and inevitable.

Lanterns carved tunnels of light,
illuminating grief on familiar faces.
No one spoke. What words
could possibly matter now?

The night funeral proceeded
without me, though I was there.
Time stretched like black ribbon
unwinding from a spool.

By morning, only disturbed earth
remained. The sun rose anyway,
indifferent to our breaking hearts,
to how the world had changed while darkness reigned.

VIGIL

The stars are pallbearers tonight
carrying the weight of our silence
across the dark cathedral of sky.

We process with candles that tremble
like questions without answers,
their light too weak to reach heaven.

The moon hangs like an unfinished thought,
half-formed and hesitant,
unable to fully illuminate our loss.

Somewhere an owl calls—
the sound of a soul being ferried
across invisible waters.

The coffin gleams darkly,
a ship embarking on the longest journey,
no return passage promised.

We are left on the shore
with flowers that will wilt by morning,
and memories that refuse to be buried.

This night funeral teaches us
that darkness has texture and depth—
like grief itself, a landscape
we must learn to navigate
without maps or guides,
only the dim light of remembrance
to show the way forward.

NOCTURNE FOR THE DEPARTED

They chose darkness for their farewell—
when shadows blur the edges of things,
when tears can fall unseen.

The night holds us in its velvet grip
as we follow the slow procession,
our footsteps percussion against silence.

Funeral at midnight: how fitting
for one who lived between worlds,
always most alive when others slept.

The cemetery breathes around us,
a living thing despite its purpose.
Headstones catch moonlight, become silver sentinels.

We place her beneath soil still warm
from yesterday's sun, as if the earth
remembered life and offered comfort.

No birds sing except the whip-poor-will,
that messenger between realms
who knows death is just another doorway.

We leave flowers that will close with dawn,
night-blooming like our sorrow,
fragrant with memories that refuse to sleep.

WHEN DARKNESS BURIES DARKNESS

The cortège winds through midnight streets
like a black river finding its way to the sea.
Lanterns swing from solemn hands,
casting light that seems to deepen shadows.

We move as if underwater,
time thickened by grief's strange alchemy.
The night funeral—an ancient ritual
when darkness buries darkness.

The coffin: a boat of cedar and brass,
carrying its passenger beyond our reach.
The priest's words scatter like moths
against the vastness of night sky.

I watch your mother's face
as they lower the rope. How still
she stands, a monument to fortitude,
while everything inside her crumbles.

The sound of earth on wood—
a heartbeat slowing to silence.
We place stones instead of flowers,
something permanent to mark impermanence.

Walking home, the stars seem closer,
as if death removes some veil between worlds.
The night funeral ends, but night continues,
teaching us how to live with absence.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Night Funeral

Under stars that pierce the velvet dark,
We carry grief in hushed procession.
Flickering candles mark our path,
As shadows dance in solemn confession.

The world sleeps while we bear witness,
To final passage, love's farewell.
Moonlight bathes the mourners' faces,
Stories only night can tell.

Footsteps echo on hallowed ground,
As earth awaits another soul.
The universe expands in silence,
While we, diminished, pay our toll.

Night cradles both the dead and living,
In arms of darkness, gentle, deep.
We return dust unto the cosmos,
And in our loss, find peace in sleep.

The Midnight Farewell

They came at midnight, bearing flowers and flame,
Procession winding through the sleeping town.
No daylight mourners these, with formal grief—
Just those who loved him best when stars looked down.

The cemetery gates creaked ancient songs,
As pallbearers moved with reverent tread.
The owl's lament pierced through the cypress trees,
A fitting requiem for one now dead.

We spoke in whispers, as if not to wake
The other souls who rested all around.
The priest's words floated up like incense smoke,
Then disappeared before they touched the ground.

By lantern light, we lowered him to rest,
The night embraced him like a final breath.
In darkness came the truth we all must face:
How thin the veil between life and death.

Nocturne for the Departed

The moon hangs heavy like a mourner's tear
Above the slow procession moving west.
Black cars with headlights cutting through the fog—
A constellation earthbound and distressed.

We gather 'neath the indifferent stars,
Our collars turned against the midnight chill.
The universe expands while we contract,
Around this absence we cannot fill.

The shovel's bite in soil breaks silence clean—
A sound so final it rewrites the past.
What was a life becomes a memory,
As darkness claims what daylight could not grasp.

In night's domain, we find strange comfort here,
Where boundaries blur between the now and then.
The veil is thinnest in these darkened hours,
When endings feel like beginnings again.

Starlit Passage

Their faces glow in candlelight,
A constellation of the grieving.
No sun to witness this goodbye,
Only moon-shadows interweaving.

The coffin gleams with polished wood,
Reflecting back what light remains.
Night wraps around our huddled forms,
As darkness dulls but does not deign

To take away the sharpened pain.
The stars above keep ancient watch,
Indifferent to our mortal loss,
Yet somehow offering their notch

Of comfort in their steady gaze.
The night wind carries whispered prayers,
As earth receives its newest guest,
And we, the living, climb the stairs

Back to a world forever changed.
The night funeral concludes in stars,
As dawn creeps in with gentle hands,
To heal what darkness cannot mar.

Under Cover of Stars

They bury their dead at night here,
When the world has turned its gaze away.
No prying eyes to witness grief unfolding,
Just the honest darkness and decay.

Lanterns swing from calloused hands,
Illuminating faces carved by time.
The shovel's rhythm marks the passing moments,
As earth reclaims what never was truly mine.

The night funeral moves in silence,
Save for boots on gravel, softly treading.
A mother's muffled sob, a father's steady breathing,
The quiet ceremony of dread unwedding.

We are all shadows in this theater,
Actors in a play without applause.
The stars our only witnesses to sorrow,
As night itself becomes the final cause

For celebration of a life now ended,
For recognition of the void ahead.
The darkness wraps around us like a blanket,
Comforting the living, honoring the dead.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Night funeral'

responses.text:
Night Funeral

A procession of shadows and flame.

Each light speaks an unspoken name.

The night wraps around us like velvet,
A cloak for the tears that we shed.
The darkness a gentle companion,
As we journey with the newly dead.

In this midnight ceremony,
Where the world sleeps but we remain,
We return dust to sacred darkness,
And find solace in shared pain.

PASSAGE

They carried him beneath obsidian skies,
Lanterns swaying like pendulums counting
The final moments of a life now passed.
The night consumed their whispers,
Digested their sorrow into stars.

I watched from the hillside,
How darkness honored darkness,
How the living bent beneath the weight
Of what they carried—not just flesh and bone,
But stories, laughter, promises unfinished.

The procession wound like a black river
