Not in cathedrals, grand and cold,
But in the whisper, "I am here."

I've known the sting of betrayal's knife,
The weight of grief too great to bear,
Yet found beneath those crushing loads
A strength beyond my own was there.

Like ancient Israel in the wild,
Pursued by Pharaoh's mighty host,
We stand between the devil's rage
And what appears a hopeless coast.

Then waters part at His command,
Impossible paths emerge from none.
The very trials that threatened death
Become the road where victory's won.

So build your towers, O world of dust,
Erect your walls of fleeting might.
My refuge stands outside of time,
A sanctuary of endless light.

The Everlasting Arms

God is the refuge of his saints,
A truth I've known since childhood days,
Yet only now in twilight years
Do I perceive its deeper ways.

For refuge isn't merely flight,
A hiding place from storms that rage.
It's transformation of the soul,
A sacred, holy pilgrimage.

I've stumbled through deserted plains,
Parched lips cracked open, begging rain.
Found oases where least expected—
Grace appearing midst my pain.

The world constructs its shelters grand,
Of wealth and status, power and fame.
But these dissolve like morning mist
When life unveils its harshest game.

So let me dwell within this truth,
This ancient, ever-present light:
God's refuge isn't where we flee,
But who we are when faced with night.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the darkest night,
When storms of life beat down with force,
And nothing seems to burn so bright.

In valleys deep where shadows dwell,
When hearts are torn and spirits break,
His presence stands, unmoved and sure,
A shelter that no fear can shake.

The world may rage with ceaseless noise,
And troubles press from every side,
Yet in His arms, we find our rest,
A peaceful haven where we hide.

No arrow flying in the day,
No terror stalking in the dark,
Can breach the walls of His embrace,
Or quench the soul's eternal spark.

So let us run to sacred ground,
Where mercy flows like gentle streams,
For God remains our constant home,
Beyond our prayers, beyond our dreams.

God is the refuge of his saints,
When thunderclouds obscure the sun,
When doubt creeps in like winter's chill,
And faith feels all but done.

Not marble walls or iron gates,
But something stronger holds us fast—
A love that stretches beyond time,
That future, present, past.

I've wandered through the wilderness,
My feet worn raw from stony paths,
Yet always found a sheltering wing,
Protection from heaven's wrath.

What mystery this—the King of All
Becomes a shield for you and me,
The hands that crafted galaxies
Now cradle us tenderly.

So when the world turns cold and harsh,
And human comfort proves too frail,
Remember where true safety lies—
In grace that cannot fail.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not built of stone but made of light,
A sanctuary beyond our sight,
Yet closer than our breath at night.

I sought Him once in temples grand,
In rituals old and doctrines deep,
But found Him in the broken places,
Where wounded spirits weep.

He dwells not in the perfect life,
But in the cracks where pain seeps through,
Transforming scars to sacred ground,
Making shattered hearts anew.

This refuge walks beside the lost,
A presence in the wilderness,
Not distant on some golden throne,
But in the depths of our distress.

So when you feel abandoned, friend,
Remember what this truth imparts—
God is the refuge of his saints,
And saints are simply broken hearts.

God is the refuge of his saints,
But what of sinners such as I?
Whose hands have built such crooked walls,
Whose words have woven countless lies?

Does mercy reach the shadowed soul,
Who stands outside the hallowed gate?
Or must I earn my way to grace,
Before it grows too dark, too late?

I've heard that saints were sinners too,
Who stumbled forward day by day,
Not perfect beings crowned with light,
But broken vessels made of clay.

Perhaps this refuge isn't earned,
But freely given, freely found,
A shelter open to us all,
Where grace and truth and love abound.

So I will trust this ancient line,
Though doubts may linger, fears remain,
God is the refuge for us all,
Who seek through joy or seek through pain.

God is the refuge of his saints,
A line from ancient sacred page,
Yet modern hearts still seek this truth,
In our distracted, digital age.

We build our walls of status updates,
Construct our towers tweet by tweet,
Yet find no shelter in the likes,
No lasting peace in fleeting heat.

Beneath the noise of endless scrolling,
A deeper hunger still remains,
For something solid, something true,
That soothes our existential pains.

What refuge waits beyond our screens?
What sanctuary past our pride?
Perhaps the answer isn't new,
But timeless wisdom long supplied.

In stillness, not in frantic pace,
In presence, not in virtual space,
God stands as refuge, now as then,
Eternal arms of endless grace.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'God is the refuge of his saints,'

responses.text:
Sanctuary

God is the refuge of his saints,
A fortress in the raging storm,
When darkness falls and courage faints,
His love keeps weary spirits warm.

Like birds that seek a sheltered nest
When thunder clouds obscure the sky,
So do our souls find perfect rest
Beneath the shadow of Most High.

What though the tempests fiercely blow,
And lightning shatters earth's domain?
Within His arms, we come to know
That worldly terrors strike in vain.

No weapon formed shall ever breach
The sacred walls of His embrace.
No sorrow's hand can ever reach
The heart that's anchored in His grace.

God is the refuge of his saints,
Unchanging through the tides of time,
Where hope renewed and faith acquaints
The soul with peace that is sublime.

Sheltered

God is the refuge of his saints,
When storms of life crash wild and near.
When human strength grows weak and faints,
His presence calms our deepest fear.

Not in cathedral walls of stone,
Nor temples built by mortal hands,
But in the heart—His sacred throne,
Where grace like living water stands.

I've wandered through the desert bare,
My throat parched dry by doubt and pain.
Yet found an oasis of care
In whispered prayers through tears like rain.

What shelter in this world compares
To arms that held the stars in place?
What sanctuary anywhere
Could match the boundless depths of grace?

So let the world its battles wage,
Let kingdoms rise and kingdoms fall.
I've found a peace that doesn't age—
A refuge answering my call.

Divine Harbor

God is the refuge of his saints,
Not made of stone but living light,
Where weary souls, beyond constraints
Find harbor in the darkest night.

I've known the sting of bitter winds,
The crash of waves against my soul,
When hope seemed frayed at all its ends,
And grief demanded heavy toll.

Yet in that space between despair
And resignation's hollow call,
I felt a presence, tender, fair—
The one who catches when we fall.

No human shelter stands so true
Against time's unrelenting tide.
No earthly fortress breaks the view
Of death that lurks on every side.

But in this refuge, strange and sweet,
I find myself both lost and found,
My brokenness made all complete,
My wandering heart at last unbound.

Beyond the Veil

God is the refuge of his saints,
A whisper in chaotic noise,
A steady hand when courage faints,
Restoring what the world destroys.

I've sought this shelter in the crowd
Of voices clamoring for truth,
Where certainty stands tall and proud,
Yet doubt persists from distant youth.

What is this refuge? Not a place
Of walls and doors and locks secure,
But something deeper—boundless space
Where love flows endless, ever pure.

Perhaps it lies between the words
Of ancient texts and modern prayers,
Or in the flight of morning birds
That rise above our human cares.

God is the refuge we don't see
With eyes trained on material things,
A sanctuary where we're free
To touch the void from which hope springs.

Unshaken

God is the refuge of his saints,
When earth gives way and mountains fall,
When morning light grows dim and faints,
His mercy answers every call.

Not built by hands of mortal might,
Nor fashioned from the dust below,
This sanctuary stands upright
When fierce and bitter tempests blow.

I've wandered paths of sharp despair,
Where thorns of doubt cut deep and clean,
Yet found a shelter waiting there
Beyond what human eyes have seen.

The world may shake with violence,
And nations rage in futile pride,
But in this strange omnipotence,
A trembling heart can safely hide.

So let me dwell within these walls
Of grace that time cannot erode,
Where peace like gentle rainfall falls
Upon my soul's abiding road.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath quilted blankets of yesterday's dreams,
Where shadows dance softly and moonlight streams
Through cracks in the armor she's built inside.

The world with its clamor and endless noise
Beats against her windows like autumn rain.
She folds into silence, again and again,
Finding solace where no one hears her voice.

But even in darkness, embers remain,
Glowing quietly, waiting for air.
The hiding is temporary, a needed prayer,
A gathering of strength to emerge again.

For she is both shelter and storm combined,
A universe contained in fragile skin.
The hiding is not weakness, but within
Lies the courage to breathe when she's realigned.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself into origami secrets,
Small enough to slip between floorboards
Where dust motes dance in forgotten sunbeams.

She crafts invisibility like an art form—
A magician's greatest disappearing act.
No spotlight. No audience. No applause.
Just the quiet triumph of absence.

The world has grown too loud with expectations,
Too bright with unblinking digital eyes,
Too heavy with the weight of performance.
She craves the luxury of going unseen.

In hiding, she rediscovers her edges,
Traces the boundaries of her true shape.
This vanishing is not cowardice but preservation,
A necessary fading to remember who she is.

Perhaps tomorrow she will emerge,
Unfurled and ready for the world's embrace.
But today, she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that wanting, finds herself again.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From the relentless march of ticking clocks,
From voices that demand and hands that take,
From mirrors that reveal what time unlocks.

She seeks the shelter of forgotten spaces,
The dusty corners where light rarely falls,
Where silence wraps around her like a cloak,
And no one waits or watches, no one calls.

The hiding isn't weakness as they claim,
But wisdom earned through battles fought alone.
A tactical retreat to sacred ground,
Where scattered parts of self can be re-sewn.

The world mistakes her absence for defeat,
Not seeing how she gathers up her power.
The seed requires darkness to transform,
Before it breaks the soil and becomes flower.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in that hiding, finds herself renewed.
A phoenix folding wings before the flame,
Knowing what's broken will be soon unglued.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To slip between the seconds of the day,
Where expectations cannot find her name
And duty's voice grows distant, fades away.

A chrysalis of quiet, self-made dark,
Where transformation happens out of sight.
Not running from but running to herself,
A sanctuary built of chosen night.

The world mistakes her absence for a loss,
As if in solitude she might dissolve.
They do not see how forests grow in silence,
How hidden roots determine how we evolve.

The hiding is a language all its own,
A dialect of self-protection, yes,
But also of discovery and growth—
A necessary pause, a soft caress.

For when she emerges, as she will,
Collected, whole, and centered in her truth,
The hiding will have served its sacred purpose:
A shelter where her spirit found its proof.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From the cacophony of everyday life.
A bird with wounded wings seeking shelter,
From storms that cut like a sharpened knife.

She builds her fortress out of silence,
Walls thick with books and unspoken thoughts.
Draws curtains against intrusive sunlight,
Ties up her heart in complicated knots.

The world mistakes her absence for sadness,
Assumes her solitude means she is lost.
They cannot fathom the freedom she finds
In spaces where their paths have never crossed.

In hiding, she discovers universes
That exist within her boundless mind.
Constellations of ideas take flight
In skies where judgment is left behind.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
And in this wanting lies profound wisdom.
For in retreat, she does not diminish—
She expands beyond her earthly prison.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath blankets woven from yesterday's dreams,
Where shadows cannot find her trembling form,
And silence wraps around her like a shield.

She builds fortresses from discarded books,
Constructs armor from unspoken words,
Draws curtains against the prying eyes of dawn,
And makes herself small against the vastness.

Sometimes the world grows teeth too sharp,
Its edges cut against her softest parts,
And all the noise becomes a hurricane
That threatens to unravel every seam.

So she retreats into herself—a cave
Of quiet contemplation, healing dark,
Where she can shed the skin that doesn't fit,
And breathe without the weight of others' gaze.

But even in hiding, she remains
A universe contained in fragile flesh,
Waiting for the courage to emerge
When hiding no longer feels like home.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself like origami wings,
Collapsing inward to a sacred space
Where judgment cannot follow, cannot find.

The world demands such constant revelation—
Bare your soul, your scars, your every thought,
But she has learned the power of concealment,
The strength in keeping something of her own.

Beneath the bed, inside a closet's dark,
Behind the mask of pleasant, practiced smiles,
She guards the fragile treasures of herself
From those who'd take without permission's grace.

Is it cowardice to seek the shadows?
Or wisdom in a world that takes and takes?
Perhaps it's simply how she finds herself
When noise and expectation grow too loud.

Hiding is not absence but presence
In a different form—potential energy,
The quiet gathering before emergence,
A butterfly not ready to unfurl.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn's final leaf that clings, afraid
To join its brothers in their earthward dance,
Trembling at the thought of being seen.

The spotlight burns her skin to ashen gray,
Each glance becomes a needle, sharp and cold.
She longs for invisibility's cloak,
To walk through crowded rooms unseen, unknown.

What trauma taught her smallness as a gift?
What voices whispered she should disappear?
The art of self-erasure learned so young—
A talent no one should perfect with age.

Yet in her hiding, worlds are born and breathe,
Creations only silence could have bred.
The quietest waters often run so deep
That divers fear to plumb their mystery.

Perhaps one day she'll shed this hiding skin,
Emerge from shadows on her own accord,
Not as escape but as deliberate choice—
Visible at last, on her own terms.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
A whisper among shouts, a shadow's child.
She slips between the cracks of conversation,
Dissolves into the corners of the room.

The world spins loud with its demanding voice—
Perform! Achieve! Be seen and counted now!
While she collects the moments in-between,
The quiet spaces others hurry past.

Her power lies in watchful observation,
In listening when others only speak.
She charts the constellations of behavior,
Maps territories of the human heart.

Don't mistake her silence for surrender,
Or absence for a lack of burning fire.
She's gathering herself like storm clouds do
Before they split the sky with lightning's truth.

Sometimes the bravest act is to retreat,
To honor boundaries when crossed too much,
To say without a word: this space is mine,
And I will share it only when I choose.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From eyes that claim to see but never do,
From voices that pronounce but never hear,
From hands that reach but rarely understand.

She builds herself a sanctuary small,
Of borrowed time and borrowed solitude,
Where expectations cannot find address
And judgment slips like water off the roof.

The hiding isn't fear—though fear exists—
But preservation of a sacred self,
The tender parts that bruise beneath the gaze
Of those who look too hard but see too little.

In hiding, paradoxically, she finds
Expansion of her truest, wildest form.
Unwatched, she stretches into fullest shape,
Unfurling parts kept folded in plain sight.

And when she emerges—if she does—
She brings with her the strength of chosen time,
The wisdom earned in voluntary dark,
A woman whole because she dared to hide.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

She shrinks into corners of rooms,

In darkness she finds her true reflection,

Sometimes hiding is not surrender

Who she was before the world wrote upon her skin.

And when she emerges, if she chooses to return,
She carries that stillness like a secret strength,
A well of peace she discovered
In the art of becoming invisible.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath layers of cotton and wool,
Curled like a question mark against the universe,
A small rebellion against being answered.

The world asks too many questions—
Who are you becoming?
What will you give?
Why aren't you more?

She builds fortresses from pillows,
Draws curtains against intrusive light,
Finds sanctuary in the gentle darkness
Where expectations cannot find her address.

It's not escape she seeks but pause,
A breath between the chapters of her story,
Space to hear her own voice
Beneath the chorus of should-be and could-be.

Sometimes hiding is the bravest act—
To protect the tender shoots of self
From the trampling feet of others' dreams,
Until they're strong enough to weather any storm.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn's last leaf clinging to its branch,
Trembling in winds of change and expectation,
Reluctant to join the fallen multitude below.

She seeks invisibility as others seek fame,
Craving the sweet anonymity of shadows,
Where judgment's sharp teeth cannot find her,
And vulnerability feels less like weakness.

In closets and corners, under blanket forts,
Behind books and screens and closed doors,
She practices the ancient art of disappearing
While remaining perfectly still in plain sight.

The world spins louder, faster, brighter,
Demanding constant presence, performance, proof.
Yet in her hiding, she discovers universes—
Worlds within that flourish in the quiet.

Perhaps tomorrow she'll emerge again,
Strengthened by her secret solitude,
But today, her absence is not emptiness
But fullness too vast for others to comprehend.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From the cacophony of expectation,
From eyes that see but never truly witness
The depths beneath her careful smile.

She dissolves into wallpaper patterns,
Becomes one with the furniture,
A ghost haunting her own life,
Present yet unseen, heard yet unlistened to.

Is it cowardice or wisdom
To retreat when the world grows too sharp,
To fold inward like night-blooming flowers
At the harsh approach of daylight?

In hiding she finds her forgotten pieces,
Scattered like stars across the floor of her mind,
Collecting them slowly, a cosmic puzzle
That only makes sense in the dark.

The world calls it absence, calls it fear,
Never understanding that in disappearing
She is more present than ever before,
Finally facing the mirror without its cracks.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To become translucent as morning mist,
Drifting between what was and what might be,
Untethered from the anchors of others' gaze.

She carves hollows in the hours,
Little caves of solitude where
The echo of her true voice
Returns to her, unaltered and pure.

It's not that she fears the light—
She has danced in its warmth before—
But rather that she needs the darkness
To remember the contours of her soul.

In a world that demands constant revelation,
Constant sharing of every thought and breath,
There is revolution in choosing concealment,
In keeping some chambers of the heart locked.

Sometimes hiding is not the absence of courage
But its most honest expression—
The courage to say: this part of me
Is mine alone to know and cherish.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
In shadows where her tears can freely fall,
Where vulnerability need not subside,
And silence wraps around her like a shawl.

The world demands a constant, beaming face,
A strength that never falters, never bends.
But in her secret, solitary space,
She needn't wear the mask that never ends.

Sometimes the weight of being seen grows vast,
Too heavy for her shoulders, slight and bare.
She craves the gentle mercy of the dark,
Where judgments cease and no one seems to care.

Perhaps in hiding, she at last can find
The scattered pieces of her fragile heart,
Reassemble what the world left behind,
And make herself a sanctuary, set apart.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the quilted comfort of her bed.
Where childhood monsters once did reside,
Now adult fears have taken place instead.

The coffee grows cold upon the sill,
Unanswered messages light up her phone.
The curtains drawn against the morning's will,
As she retreats to worlds entirely her own.

Not every disappearance speaks of pain,
Sometimes it's just the need to breathe alone.
To shed the social skin that feels profane,
And settle in the quiet she has known.

The universe inside her skull expands
When no one watches, measures, or demands.
In hiding, paradoxically, she's free—
Becoming who she's always meant to be.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like autumn leaves beneath December snow,
A temporary death, a gentle glide
Into the earth where secret rivers flow.

The constant noise of living wears her thin,
Each expectation carving out her core.
She longs to shed this too-transparent skin
And disappear behind a bolted door.

Don't call it weakness—this retreat from light.
Don't name it fear—this hunger for the dark.
It's preservation, sacred as the night,
A necessary pause, a vital mark.

For in these hidden chambers of her soul,
She gathers strength like water in a well.
In solitude, the broken becomes whole,
In silence, deepest truths begin to swell.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
A chameleon against life's harsh terrain.
Her colors shift, emotions pushed aside,
Invisibility—her shield from pain.

The spotlight burns her skin like summer sun,
Each gaze a judgment, every word a weight.
The race to be observed she cannot run,
So builds a fortress at her garden gate.

Yet hidden flowers still unfurl their bloom
Though no one stops to witness their display.
And stars burn brightest in the deepest gloom,
Their light traveling galaxies away.

Perhaps in hiding, she is most herself—
Unwatched, unfiltered, gloriously wild.
Not some trinket displayed upon a shelf,
But whole and human, wonderfully styled.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From expectations carved in marble stone.
The constant scrutiny, the turning tide
Of others' needs that drown out her own.

She builds her shelter out of quiet things:
Old books with yellowed pages, soft with time,
The whispered songs that only silence sings,
The comfort found in solitude sublime.

The world mistakes her absence for defeat,
Her stillness for surrender or for fear.
They cannot see withdrawal as retreat
Strategic, necessary, and sincere.

For in the spaces where no eyes can see,
She sheds the skin that others think she wears.
Emerging from her chrysalis, she's free—
Reborn in privacy that no one shares.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:

"You need not always stand in plain sight."

For in retreating from the world's loud gaze,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath quilted covers and morning's gentle hush,

Exhausting spirit like a fading star.
She needs these moments, near yet very far,
To recollect the pieces of her spine.

Invisibility: a gift, not shame—
A sacred pause when breathing feels too hard,
When every interaction leaves her scarred.

Perhaps in hiding she is most herself,
Not fractured into roles for others' gain,
But whole and healing, gathering her reign.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From prying eyes that never understand
The ocean depths she carries in her hand,
Or how her heart beats with the turning tide.

She seeks the shelter of forgotten things—
The dusty corners where no footsteps fall,
The quiet spaces nestled in the wall,
Where silence wraps around her like soft wings.

Don't call it weakness, this retreat from noise,
This temporary vanishing from sight.
It's here she finds her most authentic voice,
Restoring what was damaged in the light.

For those who hide are often mapping routes
To deeper truths that bravery will sprout.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Like moonlight slipping through the fingers' grasp,

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,

This gentle no to chaos and to strain.

But in forgetting how to heal from pain.

Like phoenix gathering what it learns.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,'

responses.text:
Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To vanish in the shadows of her mind,
Where whispers can't invade and tears can dry
Unseen by those who claim to be so kind.

She folds herself in corners of the day,
A paper crane with wings too weak for flight,
Collecting dust on shelves of yesterday,
Invisible beneath the harsh spotlight.

The world demands her presence like a tax,
It claims her smile, her voice, her very breath,
While she retreats inside the tiny cracks
Between what's said and what remains unsaid.

Sometimes to disappear's the only peace,
When being seen means wearing someone's dream,
When every interaction feels like lease
On parts of her that slowly come unseamed.

Yet hiding is both shelter and a cage,
A necessary darkness and a tomb,
A temporary respite from the stage,
A chrysalis, a womb, a waiting room.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
Beneath the quilted comfort of the night.
Where judgment cannot reach with prying eyes,
And vulnerability finds no light.

The world has grown too loud, too harsh, too bright—
A constant clamor for her heart and soul.
She seeks the gentle silence of retreat,
Where scattered pieces might again be whole.

Like autumn leaves that flutter to the ground,
She longs to fall where no one sees her land.
To decompose in quiet, sacred space,
Until her spirit finds the strength to stand.

Not every hiding place is built from fear;
Some sanctuaries birth a stronger self.
The seedling needs its darkness underground
Before it stretches skyward toward health.

Sometimes we hide to find what we have lost—
The essence buried under others' needs.
A momentary vanishing that costs
Far less than staying visible and bleeding.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From gazes that dissect her like a slide,
From voices that demand she be defined,
From futures others have so neatly lined.

She dreams of caves where echoes never reach,
Of forests dense where sunlight filters thin,
Of oceans deep beyond the human speech,
Where pressure might compress her sins.

The world insists on constant exhibition—
Display your thoughts! Your face! Your heart! Your pain!
She craves instead a gentle intermission,
A pause between the sunshine and the rain.

To hide is not surrender or defeat,
But rather conservation of the soul.
A gathering of strength beneath the sheet,
A private ritual to make her whole.

Sometimes the bravest act is disappearing,
Not from the truth but from distorting eyes.
The courage found in temporarily clearing
The stage where she performs her compromise.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
To fold herself between the book's worn pages,
Where ink-stained worlds provide a place to bide
And characters don't judge across the ages.

The constant hum of expectation's weight
Has carved deep valleys in her weathered hands.
She seeks the shelter of a quiet state
Where no one maps her tears or makes demands.

Invisibility—a cloak she yearns to wear,
Not sewn from shame but woven out of need.
A temporary absence from the glare
Of eyes that take but rarely plant a seed.

She doesn't hide because her light is dim,
But rather that it burns too fierce, too bright.
The world consumes her flame down to the rim
Until there's nothing left to give the night.

Sometimes we hide to find ourselves again,
Like stars that only show when darkness falls.
In solitude, we hear our voice's grain
And rediscover how to scale the walls.

Sometimes she wants nothing but to hide,
From mirrors that reflect what isn't there,
From conversations hollow as the tide,
From touches that feel more like thorny snares.

She builds a fortress out of silence, stone,
A labyrinth where only she can dwell,
A sanctuary sacred as a bone
That holds the marrow of her private hell.

The world mistakes her absence for a wound,
Her quietude for something they must fix,
They fail to see how carefully she's pruned
The branches that no longer bear her mix.

To hide is not the same as running scared—
It's cultivation of essential space,
A greenhouse where her truth can be prepared
Before it faces weather's fickle grace.

Sometimes beneath the covers of retreat,
She finds the version of herself that sings,
The one who dances on unfettered feet,
The girl who hasn't yet clipped her wings.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'And when, in the city in which I love you,'

responses.text:
And when, in the city in which I love you,
Streets unfold like paper maps between us,
I trace the lines of your absence with my steps.
Buildings rise and shadow my longing,
While traffic lights pulse in rhythm with my heart.

Here, where we once shared coffee and whispers,
Where your laughter echoed against concrete walls,
I find myself collecting memories like fallen leaves.
The subway rumbles beneath my feet,
Carrying strangers who'll never know your name.

In this city of eight million souls,
I search for fragments of you in every face.
The sky, trapped between skyscrapers,
Holds the same clouds that drift above you now.
Distance measured not in miles but in moments.

And when night falls on the city in which I love you,
Windows illuminate like stars brought down to earth,
I wonder which light might be guiding you home,
To this urban galaxy where we once belonged together,
Where my heart still beats your name into the concrete.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The rain falls like memories we cannot hold,
I stand beneath awnings, watching droplets
Trace patterns on windows like your fingers once did
Across the landscape of my skin.

This metropolis breathes your name through steam grates,
Carries your scent in the bakeries we frequented,
Holds your shadow in every doorway I pass.
The pigeons gather where you once scattered crumbs,
Patient as my hope for your return.

Street musicians play melodies that remind me
Of the songs you hummed while making morning coffee.
The subway cars rattle with conversations
That sound like echoes of promises we made
Beneath sheets tangled like our futures.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I find myself lost in familiar places,
I realize maps cannot guide me to what matters—
That geography is meaningless when measured against longing,
And every street leads back to your absence.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The dawn breaks over steel and glass mountains,
I am already awake, counting heartbeats
Like subway stops between where I am
And where you might be.

This urban wilderness grows wild with memory—
Graffiti blooms where once we pressed against brick walls,
Taxi horns call like birds of yearning,
And every crosswalk becomes a decision
To move toward or away from ghosts.

I collect ticket stubs from theaters we visited,
Receipts from restaurants where we shared plates,
Business cards from bars where we drank courage,
Assembling a paper map of what we were
Before the city swallowed our synchronized steps.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Night falls like a curtain on an empty stage,
I stand spotlit beneath flickering streetlamps,
Rehearsing lines you'll never hear, performing
For an audience of pigeons and passing strangers.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
Time moves differently through crowded avenues.
Seconds stretch like shadows at sunset,
Minutes compress in subway tunnels,
Hours dissolve in neon-lit diners where we sat.

The city wears your face in unexpected places—
Reflected in puddles after sudden rain,
Glimpsed in windows of passing buses,
Half-formed in steam rising from manholes,
Vanishing when I turn to look directly.

I carry maps creased with use but never follow them.
Instead, I navigate by landmarks of our history:
The bench where you first held my hand,
The intersection where we argued in the snow,
The rooftop where we named constellations hidden by light pollution.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I find myself collecting artifacts of us—
A matchbook from the restaurant now closed,
A photograph of streets since renamed,
The echo of your voice calling me home through the crowd.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
The seasons change without permission or pause,
I watch trees in the park shed green for gold,
As if teaching me how to release what cannot stay,
How beauty exists in both holding and letting go.

Street vendors sell flowers you once brought me,
Cafés serve the bitter coffee you preferred,
Libraries shelve the books whose passages you read aloud.
Everywhere, the geography of ordinary things
Transformed by the alchemy of your absence.

I've learned the language of this concrete landscape—
How to read the graffiti like ancient runes,
How to interpret the dance of pedestrians at crosswalks,
How to translate the symphony of car horns and construction,
Yet still cannot decipher the silence between us.

And when, in the city in which I love you,
I stand at our old meeting place and wait,
Watching strangers pass with purposeful strides,
I understand that loving someone is its own metropolis—
A place we build together, then inhabit alone.

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'I respect, another mans religion, or color or creed.'

responses.text:
Tapestry of Souls

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For in the garden of humanity, we are diverse seed.
Each flower blooms in its own sacred way,
Under the same sun, we all have our day.

Your prayers may differ from the words I speak,
Yet both climb toward heavens we equally seek.
Your skin may tell stories my own cannot share,
But beneath these coverings, our hearts beat with care.

Who am I to judge the paths others walk?
Or to silence the language in which they talk?
The Creator painted this world in spectrum wide,
Not for division, but beauty multiplied.

So let us stand together, different yet the same,
Honoring each other beyond just a name.
For respect is the bridge that spans our divide,
And love is the river on which we all ride.

Beyond Boundaries

"I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,"
A simple statement, yet profound indeed.
In these words lies wisdom's precious seed,
A call to rise above hatred and greed.

We are mosaics of different hues and thought,
Our differences, treasures that can't be bought.
Not walls to separate or cause dismay,
But windows through which light finds its way.

Your temple, church, or mosque stands tall,
My spirit hears the same sacred call.
Though our paths diverge in forest deep,
The stars we follow, the same heavens keep.

Your melanin may differ from mine,
But our blood runs red, a common sign.
Our ancestors' stories, though worlds apart,
All speak of courage and human heart.

So let us walk this earth with open minds,
Embracing the beauty diversity finds.
For when we respect each person's right to be,
We unlock the chains and set all free.

The Human Tapestry

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
Not merely words to recite, but a life to lead.
In the vast mosaic of humanity's face,
Each tile holds beauty, purpose, and place.

What divine wisdom created such varied design?
What cosmic artist painted these colors so fine?
From ebony depths to ivory's lightest glow,
From ancient rituals to faiths we've yet to know.

The prayer mat faces east, the pew faces north,
The meditation cushion, the sacred grove forth.
Different vessels sailing toward the same shore,
Different languages naming what we all adore.

Who am I to claim my path shines most bright?
When each journey seeks the same guiding light.
In your eyes I see my own reflection clear,
In your struggles, hopes that I hold dear.

So let us walk together, hand in weathered hand,
Different drums beating to rhythms grand.
For when we honor each soul's sacred worth,
Heaven's kingdom blooms here on earth.

Sacred Differences

I respect another man's religion, or color or creed,
For in these differences, humanity is freed
From the prison of sameness, the cage of one way,
The monotony of voices with nothing new to say.

Your prayers rise in languages I cannot speak,
Yet the Divine hears all who humbly seek.
Your customs strange to my untrained eye,
Hold wisdom ancient as the watching sky.

The pigments that paint our bodies' shell
Tell stories of ancestors, journeys to tell.
Geographies carved into facial lines,
Histories written in genetic designs.

Who declared one mountain peak most high?
Who claimed one single color for the sky?
The universe delights in variation's dance,
In countless ways that sunlight can entrance.

So I will stand beside you, different yet the same,
Not seeking to convert, diminish, or reclaim.
For in honoring the paths we each must walk,

prompt: Please write a poem inspired by the line: 'A POET LOSES HIS POWER FOR POETRY'

responses.text:
Silent Quill

The words once flowed like rivers wild and free,
Now trickle down to nothing but a drip.
The muse who danced with such vivacity
Has packed her bags and taken final trip.

I stare at empty pages, blinding white,
My fingers hover, trembling, over keys.
The metaphors that bloomed in darkest night
Now wither, caught in creativity's freeze.

A poet without poems—what am I?
A vessel emptied of its precious wine,
A bird whose wings are clipped, who cannot fly,
A prophet who has lost his gift divine.

Yet in this silence, something new may grow,
Perhaps the truest verse I'll ever know—
Not in the written line or crafted rhyme,
But in the living poem of passing time.

The Fading Ink

Where once volcanic verses erupted from my core,
Now sits a mountain, dormant, cold and still.
The language that I commanded with such roar
Has left me mute, bereft of words and will.

I chase the ghosts of sonnets through my dreams,
Clutching at fragments that dissolve by dawn.
My notebook drowns in half-formed themes,
As inspiration's tide has come and gone.

I walk the shore where metaphors once washed,
Collecting empty shells of what might be.
My former self—impassioned, bold, embossed—
Now faded like footprints by the sea.

Perhaps this silence is itself a verse,
A pause between the stanzas of my life.
The greatest poem may be the universe
Of unwritten words that cut like a knife.

Wordless

I used to catch wild words like fireflies,
Preserving light in jars of crafted verse.
Now darkness spreads across my inner skies,
And silence grows like something of a curse.

The dictionary sits, a dusty tomb
Of possibilities I cannot reach.
My mind, once garden, now a barren room
Where echoes die before they form to speech.

They say that poets never truly die
As long as someone reads their written heart.
But what of those whose wells run dry,
Whose art abandons them, whose words depart?

I trace the shape of poems I used to know,
Like touching scars where beauty used to grow.
Perhaps in wordlessness I'll finally see
The truths that language never showed to me.

The Unstrung Lyre

The instrument lies broken in my hands,
Its strings untuned, its music fled away.
I stand before expectant, waiting fans
With nothing but my silence left to say.

Remember when my verses sparked and burned?
When metaphors unfurled like morning glories?
The tide of language has so swiftly turned—
I've lost the magic key to all my stories.

A poet stripped of poetry remains
A shadow of identity, half-formed.
I search the landscape of my barren brains
For seeds of verse that weather every storm.

Perhaps this too shall pass, this drought of soul,
This emptiness that carves me like a hole.
Or maybe this is wisdom's final gift:
To learn that even wordless, I exist.

Fallen Oracle

I was a vessel once for sacred fire,
A channel for the universe's song.
The muses whispered all that I require—
But now they've gone, and I no longer belong.

The kingdom of my mind, once lush with phrase,
Lies fallow, cracked, and desperate for rain.
I wander through the maze of empty days,
Collecting shadows, harvesting my pain.

A poet without poetry is what?
A priest without a god, a bird unwinged,
A lover left alone, a door that's shut,
A bell whose final toll has just now ringed.

Yet in this loss, perhaps there's something gained—
The freedom from the duty to create.
What if the truest poems remain unnamed,
And silence is the highest art of fate?

The Wordless Bard

A poet loses his power for poetry—

Yet in this silence, something stirs—

Abandoned by Verse

A poet loses his power for poetry—
A captain drifting on silent seas.
The compass broken, the stars obscured,

I chase the ghosts of former lines,
Echoes fading through corridors of time.

Is this the price for years of flight?

To walk among the ordinary souls,

Perhaps this void is but a space

A transformation through the pain—
The death of verse for life to gain.

For in the silence after song,

The truest poetry might appear
When all pretense has disappeared.

The Unwritten

I used to dance with language, wild and free,
Coaxing beauty from the mundane world.
Metaphors were weapons in my arsenal,
Rhymes, the steady heartbeat of my soul.

A poet loses his power for poetry
Like earth loses warmth to winter's grip.
The alchemy that turned thought to gold
Now yields only lead, heavy and cold.

I stare at blank pages, once my kingdom,
Now foreign lands I cannot navigate.
The ink has dried within my fountain pen,
As tears have dried upon my weathered face.

What curse is this that steals a craftsman's tools?
What thief so cruel to rob one's very voice?
The universe that once spoke through my hands
Now silent as a stone beneath the stars.

Yet in this wordless void, I'm strangely free—
No longer servant to the perfect phrase.
Perhaps the greatest poem remains unwritten,
Lived instead through quiet, ordinary days.

For maybe when a poet loses poetry,
He finds at last the truth beyond all words.
